reviewText:
Saint's Row IVDeveloper: Volition
Publisher: Deep Silver

Introduction
==========
In the first thirty minutes of Saints Row IV, you’ll shot your way through a military base before disarming a nuclear bomb in flight, which wins the hearts of the nation and the presidency of the United States. You’ll sign off on a cure for cancer or end world hunger, and fend off an alien attack with a turret gun on the White House lawn. It’s immediately clear that Saints Row has finally abandoned any of the pretence at gritty underworld realism that was so at odds with the slapstick of previous games in the series. This is the game that finally provides an appropriate thematic context for Saints Row’s mechanics, one that sees the Steelport Saints emerge from Grand Theft Auto’s shadow once and for all.

Gameplay
==========
In Saints Row IV, you once again take on the role of the leader of the Saints, a now globally recognised gang. The good times don’t last long though, as humanity’s worst fears are realised when an evil alien race known as the Zin invades Earth. You and the other members of the Saints are held hostage in a simulated version of Steelport. With the help of your hacker friends Kinzie and Matt, and combat backup from the rest of the crew - including Vice President Keith David - you must disrupt the system enough to break free and hopefully save the human race.

The game plays much the same as Saints Row: The Third. You control a customizable Boss of the Saints through a variety of missions and tasks in the simulation in an attempt to disrupt it and do some damage, enough to save your crew and escape. Ultimately culminating with a final showdown against the Emperor of the Zin Empire, you will meet some new faces along the way and even some from past games in the series (Sorry, not spoiling it for you)!

The main features of Saints Row IV are the superpowers. As you progress the story, you'll unlock several overpowered abilities that are designed to help you in your quest to dominate the simulation. Super Sprint allows you to travel faster than any car ever could, and combined with Super Jump you can clear multiple city blocks in a matter of seconds. You have a limited stamina bar, but it isn’t long before it becomes irrelevant. At that point you can leap around to your heart’s content. You also get access to telekinesis, elemental energy blasts, and even a Super Stomp which, when fully upgraded, hits with the power of a nuke, clearing an entire block! These powers are a fresh new addition that can be used for even more zany antics around the Steelport simulation.

Your menu is where you'll be spending your hard earned cash (cache) and clusters to upgrade your abilities and superpowers. Honestly, you will spend several hours just jumping around the simulation collecting these clusters. Since the platforming is so good, it almost becomes a compulsion to head straight towards a cluster when you see it.

The main story is where Saints Row IV shines. The writing is superb, although you will definitely want to have played at least some of Saints Row: The Third to appreciate a lot of the jokes. The game is filled with laugh out loud moments, not only from the dialogue, but even just from the missions you find yourself taking on. Each of your crew members has their own loyalty mission, which grants them superpowers of their own upon completion. These are the big side missions that are worth doing, while other quests in the game aren’t really necessary unless you’re going for all of the achievement. The main missions alone will take you a decent amount of time, perhaps around 10-15 hours, and to complete everything in the game will take up to around 20-25 hours, especially if you want to get Gold rating in all challenges.

The Matrix came out 16 years ago, and only semi-recently did I even get to see all of the films. It’s getting to the stage that movies get to when you hear your friends saying “What do you mean you’ve never seen The Matrix!?”, and then say to themselves “...oh I’m getting old”. However, as one of the most important films in its genre, you can forgive Saints Row IV for making quite so many references to it, which after finally watching the films myself stood out like a sore thumb.  Everything from “finding an exit”, down to diving into the very bodies of enemies and destroying them from within gets a mention. Heck, the whole simulation idea is straight out of the Matrix.

The combat still holds up well too. In addition to all the well-known weaponry from the previous game, you have access to all kinds of new flashy alien tech. The Dubstep Gun, The Singularity Gun and the Inflato-Ray are some of the most amusing, and most satisfying things to use in any recent video game. Mayhem missions return, where you cause as much damage as possible in the time allotted. Insurance Fraud has you literally playing in traffic to generate money. Instead of car racing, you will be racing using your super jump and super sprint. You can hack shops in a minigame which is a slightly altered and more infuriating version of Pipeline. These side activities provide a distraction from the main quest line, but none of them are particularly worth spending too much time on unless you are a completionist.

Graphics
==========
Although it is a simulation, you will be familiar with Steelport if you played the previous game. The landscape is much the same, with most of the old locations in the same place. It is noticeably different though, with a liberal scattering of alien hardware, and a lack of sky and water.

I had mixed feelings on the way the game looks. I wasn’t a big fan of the dark and gloomy visuals of the simulation, but they eventually grew on me. The way every texture shimmers every now and then as the simulation occasionally slows up is actually pretty cool.

Overall the game looks very nice. Some of the billboards and signs scattered thoughout are surprisingly detailed, not to mention hilarious. The cars still look as great as ever, and you can still customize them any way you choose. Though with access to the superpowers, you will probably not being using any vehicles as your main mode of transportation.

Sound and Music
==========
Boasting a massive soundtrack featuring over 100 different tracks, Saints Row IV has your musical needs covered as you drive your stolen vehicles around the Steelport simulation. You can find a full list online easily. There's something for everyone, as the soundtrack covers some very broad tastes in music, even classical.

Performance
==========
For me the game hovered around 40-50FPS even when it seemed like the entire screen was exploding, or when I was running at hundreds of miles per hour through city streets leaving a trail of destruction in my wake. The only time it occasionally hitched was during an autosave, but it was barely noticeable. I didn't have any other issues at all. The game has full controller support, and can be enjoyed using a controller or mouse/keyboard. It's easy to play using either one.

Final Thoughts
==========
Overall Saints Row IV is a marvellously enjoyable game, while still suffering from a few of the complaints that the series has always had. The main quests are great, and although the side missions are not painful to play, they don’t quite pack the same punch. If you played and enjoyed Saints Row The Third, then picking up this sequel is a must. Equally if you’re looking for a game that lets you run around as a badass with special powers.

Gameplay Demo
==========
https://youtu.be/RumGX_dVcIA

Nerd House Verdict:
==========
A Must Play
Be sure to check out Nerd House Gaming for more reviews!

reviewText:
While dressed as a pirate, I killed aliens with the power of music while the bystanders danced, seemingly oblivious to the carnage happening right beside them.

This game doesn't just jump the shark, it also clones the shark, gives the cloneshark laser eyes, and then makes them BOTH have a dance off, while wearing pretty blue dresses.

If you hate fun, avoid this game at all costs.

Pros:
- Yes, there are many ladies of the night. What? Oh, right.
- Yes, there are many sports played at a professional level in the game. What NOW? Seriously? SIGH. FINE.
- No, this game contains no Protoss, because copyright is a real thing. WHAT? OH, FOR THE...WELL, WHAT EVEN IS A 'PRO' THEN? Wait, what? That's ALL? I'm starting again.

Good stuff about the game:
- This is easily, by far, without any doubt or exception, the funniest game I own. Although SR3 comes in a close second. 'Comes'. Heh.
- More customisability than (so-called) Real Life. Not even joking. Unless you consider that Real Life includes this game - then that just confuses the issue. So don't do that.
- Easily the best music of the series, and possibly 'any game ever'. In my opinion, at least.
- The gameplay consists of one main storyline and a whole bunch of mini games. I like this.
- KEITH DAVID. In general.
- STILL more realistic than most of the GTA series.
- Okay, that last one probably isn't true.
- Probably.
- Boys can wear dresses, and girls can wear pants. That's one step up from most games. If you care about that kind of thing. Which I don't. But you might.
- If you're insane like me, and try NOT to kill pedestrians/civs, then this game will allow you to do so guilt-free (because of the storyline).
- It's not Day One: Garry's Incident, because who needs that? Still, this is true of most games, I suppose.
- The boob physics are okay.
- Carnival psychics are not okay, not in my book.
- THE MURDER KING RETURNS! No, not Genki. Although, him too.
- I hate it when I can actually achieve my goals in life because I don't get distracted, and this game is excellent in that regard.
- This game will never expect you to listen to Nickleback, or Creed.
- It won't talk about how (insert TV show) is the greatest thing ever made, even though said show is clearly just a rehash of a short film, or comic, or feature film, or a brand of canned tuna, or whatever.
- The game doesn't send a message to your friends on social media everytime you turn left, or jump. I am looking directly at you, PeopleVilleFarmSocietyPetCandyLand.

Cons:
- Yes, most of the Saints Row are ex-cons. What? Oh. English, eh? It's weird.

Not-so-great-stuff about the game:
- There's no Burt Reynolds.
- Some people may not like the fact that vehicles become redundant after the first half-hour. I didn't really care.
- The gameplay consists of one main storyline and a whole bunch of mini games. Some may not like this.
- I couldn't find the 'Feel Boss - 5$' guy ANYWHERE. I had this whole storyline in my head where the Saints worked undercover for a secret organisation, and the Feel Boss guy was their handler, and I...probably could have kept that info inside of my head. Oh well, no doubt I will delete it before I post the review. I'm sure I will remember, because my memory is top notch.
- Not enough Mighty Boosh references. Unlike my reviews.
- No Old Gregg.
- See? Mighty Boosh reference. BAM!
- You can't kill Dex.
- Aussies will be reminded about their Nanny Government every time they want to Co-op. And who needs that?
- Not enough Frank Welker (I hope the 3 of you that just got that found it really funny/apt. The rest of you can ignore this comment).
- There are escort missions. But they involve actual 'escorts', so I gave this one a free pass.
- That last one was a blatant lie, I just really wanted to use that gag.
- There's STILL no Burt Reynolds. I cannot overstate this enough.

Yeah, that's a big deal for some people. Horses for courses, and ponies for - um - something that rhymes with ponies. Stonies? Oh, I quit.

JUST BUY THE DAMN GAME, OKAY?

reviewText:
The Saints are back! Well, sort of. Fans of the first 3 Saints games may be in for a bit of a surprise, that is either going to impress them, or send them into a fit of rage. While other Saints games have been no stranger to going way out into left field, the 4th entry into this series seems to push the envelope even further. So far in fact that it seems like a completely new genre entry into the series. I'm sure by now you know the gist of the game. The gist is that you are no longer tied the laws of normal physics. Why? You progressively and eventually achieve becoming a mother #$%@ing superhero! Oh, and did I mention you are also the President of the United States? Yeah, from just a gangbanger, to a man in tights! Or whwtaever you want to wear to be honest.


Saints Row completely flips the script of previous Saints games, and has you now instead of fighting rival gangs, taking on a legion of aliens bent on destroying everything you care about. You'll meet familiar faces from the past, and run and gun or jump (over buildings mind you) and pound the ground with a bevy of your closest friends from the Saints universe. And Keith David too!

Yeah, you can run at lightning speeds, jump long distances, use telekinetic powers, and a lot more. The melee fighting is a lot better, but still a little lacking. However, punches go hard this time, so it's a lot more satisfying. Like punching a car, and seeing it knocked back quite a distance. You still get guns and other weapons (and LOTS of skins for them). And the way the game flows in combat, you'll find yourself mixing it up with all assortments of moves. Mainly due to limited ammo, and a meter for combat superpowers. This way you're not just spamming one thing over and over again. This makes for some fast and furious action, and I love it!

As far as traveling goes, you do get vehicles. But with how fast you can move in the game, they almost feel like an afterthought. That is of course for aerial vehicles, which can still be useful. This being because while you can jump super high, or launch yourself very far, and even glide long distances, you still never get the ability to fly.

As for the lack of interest in using vehicles which most people find not necessary, the game features the ability to listen to your favorite radio stations usually found in the vehicles, now outside of the vehicles at any time. And this my friends, is quite the dream. The soundtrack has some choice tunes, featuring a wide assortment of genres, and throwback classics. I was floored when I ran into a pack of alien enemies, and The Touch" by Stan Bush started playing. It made me feel...well...It made me feel like a bad ♥♥♥! The cheesy 80's centric music blaring while I'm zooming in and out of these enemies

reviewText:
Infinitely cool, more badass than Wesley snipes in blade 1 and as solid as a sand box game gets without you actually being it. All the customization of every saint’s row game put together with the option to share your mentally provoking creations and abominations of god. Cars and driving are only useful for about the first hour of the game then only become another weapon in your endless armoury of maddening weapons and tools of destruction. In short, the game makes no sense what so ever, the story is fickle and rushed and the character; re-hashed and forgettable – however, this game could have 10,000 flaws and you’d forget them all quicker than you noticed them. It’s a gem, a rare, other-worldly hunk of meteor dust, crystalized in the form of a manageable download ready for you to explore and make “wat” you’re most used word in your vocabulary. I would spend more time on this game, but I’m not sure where it would end. Needless to say, SR4 has an insane amount of playability, especially if you have a friend to play with and is well worth every penny you can throw at it.

Not an epic masterpiece, not a timeless classic but an array of creativity and kookiness only truly experience and masterful game creators and developers could imagine and forge into this almost abomination of a title.

Like sandboxes? You’d be silly not to own this and love it like a family pet.

12.5/10

reviewText:
Saints Row IV is an over the top, open world over the shoulder shooter set in a virtual world similar to the Matrix. After quickly becoming the president, aliens take over the planet and lock everyone away in their own virtual world. The city is the same city from Saints Row: The Third, but now since its a virtual world, its always night and everything has neon lights like Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon. It plays the same as previous Saints Row games or any over the shoulder shooter, but with a big new addition, super powers. It might be the same town, but you play it completely different. Why steal a car and drive, when you can run faster than any car and super jump up tall buildings to wall jump even higher. You won't spend time on the streets, but on top of buildings as well. You'll even get magical powers like telekinesis, fireballs and ice to dispatch enemies. These spells replace the throwing items like grenades. Each spell has a cool down, but its infinite.

To start, you're the same character from previous games, which is to say yourself. Your own customized character that I created a drunken 80s rock star with a mustache and a gritty accent. You can even chose Nolan North as a voice. The entire crew from the previous game is back and you'll need to save them from their own virtual Hells. This is where the game pulls from the past history of the franchise and puts a nightmarish spin on them. You'll get to hear some of the franchise's greatest cameos like Neil Patrick Harris and Mila Kunis. Not to mention Kyle David plays himself as the Vice President.

The game walks the line between over the top comedy and action with great gameplay. Comedy games never really hit home for me, but this one managed to strike a chord. The humor isn't like the sexual comedy of Saints Row: The Third. Instead, there's some excellent parody of other games, like a Metal Gear Solid mission, complete with box crawling and shooting 2 lights when 1 bullet would take out a guard. Even movie parodies like a Ghostbusters 2 giant energy drink can fighting a giant statue. The entire game is its own version of the Matrix movie. You get rescued like Neo, into the real world on a spaceship where you're free to hop into the virtual version of Steelport or romance some of your crew. Its all part of the comedy. The licensed 90s music really heightens the experience and really clinches some of the moments. Climbing a rocket headed for space, you'll hear Aerosmith's I don't wanna miss a thing." Visiting a club full of blow up dolls
date: you'll hear "Insane in the Membrane" from Cypress Hill.\n\nIts not just visual gags and parody. The dialog is another strong point.  I think that because the characters are less distracting and gimmicky
recommended: the dialog stands out that much more. Your crew feels believable
hoursPlayed: while still making fun of one another and themselves. I felt they're still a big crazy family / street gang / presidential cabinet.\n\nThe story missions offer a diverse array of activities. You won't just be fighting and shooting. As an example

reviewText:
Saints Row IV is a culmination of what happens when you combine stellar gameplay and design, with over-the-top antics and crazy missions. There are so many things developer Volition did right that make Saints Row IV such an enjoyable, replayable adventure, however outlandish or warped its turns take along the way.

In the first few hours of my playthrough of Saints Row IV, I became the President of the US, cured cancer, was captured by aliens called Zin, saw the Earth blow up, ate pancakes for breakfast and stubbed my toe. While all of this may sound so cliché, Saints Row IV then opens itself up to a plethora of player customization, ridiculous weapons and over-powered weapons. Saints Row IV was designed to be destroyed, but these basics are just a small amount of what it has to offer.

After leaving the '50s re-enactment of Steelport, you return to a simulation of the city that has been overrun by Zin. As soon as you enter Steelport, you are introduced to clusters. Clusters are the 'super-power currency' to Saints Row IV. Collect enough of these, and you can upgrade and beef up abilities such as Super Sprint, Blast, and Telekinesis. The latter all have elemental variants, from the fundamental 'Fire' and 'Freeze', to bigger and better things like 'Explosion' and 'Mind Control'. These new attack methods can be used at any time inside the simulation, and are what make Saints Row IV a new experience to fans of the Open World genre.

Steelport's map is dotted with collectibles and minigames. One of my personal favourite minigames was Professor Genki's Mind Over Murder game, which was hilariously silly and stupid, but so enjoyable. I especially loved the game-show-style commentary incorporated in it, with two hosts discussing how I played as I went along. There are also Audio Logs that contain fragments of peoples' past and Zinyak statues to destroy.

Although Saints Row IV is mainly about the constant alien bloodshed in the wake of the apocalypse, the Saints' story is one I will remember. Behind the impudent facade a lot of the characters portray is a level of caring, they want to help their friends and they all care for each other. No matter what obstacles they overcome, the Saints have the power to pull through. This isn't to say there won't be falling outs, but for the majority of the main missions, I never felt like I was uninterested.

Side quests, on the other hand, were Saints Row IV's downfall. I saw them as 'time fillers', to make the game appear longer, and to give you a little incentive for when you finish at the end. Sometimes, I was happy to take on Matt Miller's boring missions, only so I could receive the Mind Control reward at the end. I'm so glad the side quests were optional, because if the story was as bland and monotonous as these, I would have put down my controller and not picked it up again. Most of the side quests were what you would sort of expect. While you were asked to do things from different people, it was always the same 'Go here, blow stuff up, come back.' style of side quests you would expect. This isn't to say that blowing the stuff up wasn't fun, it's just the way they were instigated showed no sign of distinction between them.

Saints Row IV presents itself as an in-your-face, balls-to-the-wall style game that doesn't back down on anything it delivers. But that doesn't mean you can't spend quality time making countless changes to how you look. There are so many different customization options at the Image As Designed plastic surgery, I spent about three hours deciding between a wide-eyed Elder Scrolls Argonian-like man with a female voice, or a purple hulk with blue hair and a Cockney accent. I finally settled for something simpler and human-looking, with a thick British accent. I felt compelled to keep it, even though I knew I could make something better. Something about the original character you create stays with you, and sometimes I didn't even want to change my outfit in fear of 'losing' my character's personality.

Overall, Saints Row IV is an over-the-top, blasé third-person adventure, complete with aliens and an impeccable story. Saints Row IV is outrageous, but under its whole bad-♥♥♥ guise lies a wonderfully constructed joy to play. It is entertaining, stupid, and just plain fun. Volition sure knows how to give players a good time.

reviewText:
Notable features:
Kinzie Kensington
You can punch anyone in the dangly bits and kill them instantly
Run up buildings
The game actually references pop culture instead of peppering its dialogue with memes
Seven voice packs for the playable character: 3 male, 3 female, and Nolan North
No gang bangs (which is a good thing!), but you can bang members of the gang
A gun that shoots infinite knives
Extremely lenient QTEs (even my fumbly fingers could hit them)
Saints Row has come a long way. It has evolved from a simple GTA clone into a bizarre exploration of game tropes and a rampant power fantasy set against a vaguely GTA inspired background. If you're like me and you love mobility and highly emergent gameplay you'll enjoy the hell out of SRIV. Super speed, super jump, air dash, backflip suplex, taser SMG, nuclear ground pound, beam katana, car punt, simply being naked, lighting yourself on fire, and money hailstorm are all real abilities in this game and all perfectly usable in combat. The number of possible strategic combinations is mind-boggling. And not once during the whole experience does it stop being fun.

The only things that could possibly be called a downside to SRIV are the rift missions, where you enter a neon-punk void and a robotic orb snarks at you while you struggle to complete seemingly simple tasks. By toughing them out, though, you can add even more potent abilities to your arsenal, such as water walking, immunity to fire, and the ability to shrug off an explosion like it's nothing, so they're worth the mild discomfort.

In short, this game is worth twice what they're charging for it and more besides. Buy it.

reviewText:
Let me preface this review by stating that I believe that Saints Row 2 is vastly superior to Saints Row: The Third. Saints Row IV takes the all the batshit insane parts of SR:TT and amps up the crazy to 11. This game is designed with the purpose of being silly fun.

Two great things about this game are the solid writing and good soundtrack, things sorely missing from Saints Row: The Third and present in other previous installments. The plot of this game, despite being overblown and ridiculous has good character writing and a good sense of wit behind it.

Saints Row IV takes place in a simulation of Steelport, the city of Saints Row: The Third. While a lot of assets have been reused in SRIV there are plenty of tweaks to the map which make it feel new enough to not just be a rehash of the previous game. The same philosophy applies to the gameplay, which takes the same core of SR:TT but adds superpowers. Superpowers dramatically switch up the gameplay from an open world sandbox in the vein of GTA to one more in the vein of Prototype and inFamous.

Did I mention the customisation? There is extensive customisation in this game in items such as cars, weapons, clothes and the player character themselves. Now while this customisation isn't as intricate or in detail as SR2 it's a marked improvement over SR:TT.

If Saints Row 2 is one of the greatest open world games ever made and Saints Row: The Third is a cynically produced title that attempted to cash in on what made SR2 popular but completely missed the point then Saints Row IV is someone in between the two. The devs decided to take the insane aspects from Saints Row: The Third and run with them and magniy it to an insane degree but it has the things that made Saints Row 2 great but in a different setting.

I can easily recommend this to anyone who likes fun in their games.

reviewText:
So, this game really is as awesome as it looks.  In the same way that SR2 jumped in craziness to SR3, it's just as crazy a jump to SR4.....except this is waaaaaay more fun.  Driving in this game becomes the least interesting way to travel around the world when compared to super sprinting and leaping over buildings, weapons get even crazier courtesy of things like the black hole gun, dubstep gun, and the 'Murica Weapon.

When you have the excuse of a simulation for everything, you can get away with a lot of hilarious things.  You end up in a 1940s styled world a couple of times, you fight a gigantic soda can mascot, and even end up playing a 2D styled beat 'em up at one point in time.  Honestly, I haven't had this much fun in a video game in a very long time, and this is easily GOTY for 2013 barring something even more fantastic coming along, which I doubt highly.

But stop reading this!  Go buy it now!

reviewText:
Saints Row IV is an experience the series has never seen before. While the core formula of accepting missions from NPCs, completing Diversions, taking territory and causing as much mayhem as possible remains the same, the inclusion of new super powers and abilities elevates the experience to a higher degree of madcap fun. The story of the game’s development is well known, starting out as DLC for Saints Row The Third until Volition determined that a much bigger game was possible. And this is most certainly a big game. Those concerned that Saints Row IV is nothing more than a glorified expansion can put their fears to rest. This is, hands down, the best game in the Saints Row franchise.
Set an indeterminable amount of time after Cyrus Temple was kicked out of Steelport, the Third Street Saints are once again thrust into battle against S.T.A.G. after Cyrus acquires a nuclear rocket and intends to blow up Washington D.C. and blame it on the international celebrity gang. Led by MI-6 agent Asha Odekar, the Boss, Shaundi, Kinzie, Matt Miller and Pierce are able to defeat Cyrus, but not before he launches the weapon. After disarming the nuke in a wonderfully dramatic fashion, the Boss is awarded the prestigious honor of becoming the President of the United States.
The leadership is short lived due to an invasion by the Zin Empire, lead by the eloquent and Jane Austen-loving Emperor Zinyak. After the Presidential cabinet and a significant amount of Earth’s population are captured, the Boss is thrown into a Matrix-style simulation of Steelport. With the assistance of Kinzie and the Third Street Saints, the Boss begins a campaign to free humanity from the Zin, both in and out of the simulation.
In a great number of ways, Saints Row IV plays quite similarly to Saints Row The Third. You’ll wander around the large city completing story missions, a massive laundry list of Diversions retooled for the new game, character specific side quests, and upgrade character and Homie abilities all in the name of freeing humans from Zinyak’s rule.
Combat continues to entertain with a large assortment of weapons guaranteed to cause as much destruction as possible. The game’s biggest addition is the large suite of upgradeable superpowers that shakes the Saints Row gameplay experience to its very core. Because Steelport is a stand-in for the Matrix, there are rules to the system that can be bent and, thanks to Kinzie, broken. One might think that the ability to run faster than a speeding pimpmobile and jump tall bordellos in a single bound would be enough to break the game. Not so! These powers instead bring the game to a new level of fun and insanity.
Powers make for more enriching and diverse combat scenarios. Why duck behind low walls or move in and out of cover when you can jump ten feet into the air, land on a roof and pick off targets from above? Need to increase the distance between you and a group of foes? Super sprint down the street and lick your wounds before heading back in the fray. Knock enemies down harder than a case of donkey beer with a ground stomp. With these powers, combat becomes a completely opened ended affair. While shooting enemies can be fun on its own, mixing gunfire with Freeze Blast, Telekinesis and Mind Control can result in a great deal of creative brutality. Having these options is especially useful when you max out your Wanted meter, as the Zin are relentless in their attempts at killing you.
If there’s a downside to the implementation of super powers, its that they render vehicles spectacularly pointless, so much so that the fun dips slightly when a mission puts you in the driver’s seat.
Creating a game within a virtual Steelport provides a unique and astonishingly well realized visual aesthetic. The city, shrouded in a light red tinge, is given a futuristic facelift. Because the city is a computer simulation, you can’t go very far without seeing elements of the computer software, with bits of code that run underneath wall textures and varying degrees of artifacting on vehicles, NPCs and the game world itself. In one mission the city buildings and NPCs warp and degrade in many different ways and in another, textures are replaced by colored ASCII code. All this is done at the drop of the hat and without any stress on the game’s integrity. It really is an impressive technical feat.
Where the game shines brightest is in the mission design. A virtual setting allows Volition to not concern themselves with developing scenarios confined to a real, if cartoony, world. I want to emphasize that many, MANY, of the mission types you’ll find here represent some of the most inspiring pieces of game design for both the franchise and the open world genre. By the end of the game, Saints Row IV will have served not only as an homage to the entire franchise but also to the last twenty years in gaming.
I really enjoyed my time with Saints Row IV, far more than the previous two games. I found its story to be genuinely engrossing as it involves much more than eliminating street gangs and taking out the leader of an international crime syndicate. Saints Row IV is a long game as well, taking me close to fourteen hours to finish. I’m already planning on playing through the game again to see what effect a different choice has on the result of one particular mission. With surprises around every corner, Saints Row IV stands head and shoulders above previous games in the series and is a shining jewel in the open world genre.

reviewText:
Saint Row IV

I was really excited to play this game! I had huge expectation about it, cause I really liked SR2 and SR3, SR3 was for me a non-stop fun!
so, after I got this game, I launched it... and right at the get-go, I was in tears!

Story
The story is just crazy-funny-weird-unrealistic as you would imagine Saints Row,  You have been elected to be the President of the United States,
After a few years of ruling with swag on you lovely nation, you've been attacked by Aliens, which abducted you friends and you, but, the Boss alien isn't satisfied with just abducting you,
He placed you in a virtual prison\world which is SteelWater city, and from here, you try to hack the system and get out of the 'program' (Matrix anyone?).

Graphics
Graphics is good! it's almost like SR3 but obviously they added some more features and it's a bit more nicer.
now, I can't say it looks amazing like Metro: LL, they weren't trying to make a game looking like that, and TBH, you would need a Monster system to run something like that since it's an open-world.
anyways, for me, the graphics works.

Gameplay
And now for the Pièce de résistance!
I think someone in the Backlog Attack! chat said that this game is a game that meant to be a parody about games, at first, I didn't know what he meant, but after playing the game, it's so true!
How will I explain this? at first you have a stealthy mission reminding me Splinter Cell, in another scene, I was reminded of MGS, and it just continues like this, when you'll try it, you'll understand, I'm sure.
The game features many types of mini-games just like SR3, some different and some are same like Insurance Fraud.
now, they've added the super powers feature and it's just pure awesomeness, if you've played Prototype, it's just like that, and it's really fun!!

Conclusion
Some say that SR4 is just a huge DLC for SR3, but IMO it's not, and if it is, then it's worth the money!
The game is just 100% fun, you can do whatever you want, how ever you want, the dialogs and cutscenes are just hilarious!
the game got tons of references to other games and movies which I found really funny and fun to find.
bottom line, this game is worth the money! it's really really fun!
Buy this game when you can! you won't be disappointed!

reviewText:
I understand why a lot of people do not like the 4th episode of Volition's critically acclaimed series. With the superpowers we now have the game is a bit too over-the-top. Also, there's no real new area here as the city of Steelport remained the same. It looks a bit different due to the alien invasion (actually, the huge alien ship in the air looks stunning and is pretty cool), but the areas remained the same.

So, in essence, Volition only added a new storyline which now sees our favourite gang pitted against the invading forces of an alien race. And the battle mainly takes place in a Steelport which is not a real city but the virtual reality version of an already destroyed place. So, as a nod to Matrix we, just like Neo, can easily do in this world whatever we want. With the superhuman abilities we can run up on the sides of buildings, can leap forward to great distances and following a charged-up jump we can glide in the air for a long time. This gameplay is similar to the one we had in Prototype so those of you who liked that franchise will see that this one plays pretty familiar.

The downside this approach brings with itself is the fact that as you unlock fast running pretty early own there's no real point in driving any car in the game as getting from point A to point B is much easier by running, jumping and gliding instead of using any vehicles. In fact, later on running right next to people or cars make these fly away due to the sheer force of your fast speed so to a certain degree getting into a car while running is a bit difficult.

However, if you think about it Volition could not have gone in any other direction. After all, in The Third we already kicked the arses of the rival gangs of Steelport and even fought the government's so-called STAG programme. So, taking one step forward was obvious towards aliens. And the jokes and hilarious moments including some excellent cameos of famous people (Keith David, Roddy Piper, Neil Patrick Harris) are still there.

And this was always the real deal for me: how funny this franchise was, how silly the missions were and how great dialogues the Saints had. When completing the story and the game's many side missions I clocked around the same number of hours I did with The Third. For me, the 4th installment of the Saints did deliver and I think Volition did a great job once again.

reviewText:
In Saints Row IV you are the President of the United States and the Earth is attacked by aliens. After failing to defeat them, you find yourself in the Matrix and you must learn to use this to your advantage to stop the alien invasion.
Saints Row IV plays just like Saints Row: The Third. But early in the game, you start picking up data clusters and taking down the Wardens of the simulation, allowing you to unlock special abilities. You will be able to be as fast as a car or to jump like Spider-Man, later you will be also able to glide around.
There are a lot of movie and videogame parodies in the game such as They Live, The Matrix, Inception, Mass Effect 2, Mortal Kombat, Metal Gear Solid, Streets Of Rage, Riddick and many many more.
There is a wide range of things you will do in story missions. There are lots of throwbacks to Saints Row 1,2, and 3 throughout the game. You also have a space ship very similar to Mass Effect where you can chat with the crew and romance everyone. So, the story will never become boring.
Activities have taken a big change, instead of a pass or fail system, it is now bronze, silver and gold. You will also unlock more powers, perks for powers, costumes and weapons through beating activities.
There's a lot of new stuff like a telekinetic Professor Genki competition, platforming rifts, speed rifts.
Saints Row IV has nearly all of the original character voices from the first 3 games. There is also again a big music selection. A great selection of dance, hip hop, 90s and more you can listen from the in-game radio stations.
The graphics are nearly the same as in Saints Row: The Third.
Overall I think Saints Row IV is also a fantastic game. It is a lot of fun to play, especially if you play with a friend.

Sounds 10/10
Graphics 7/10
Gameplay 8/10
Atmosphere 8/10

If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:
http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guides
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curation

reviewText:
The first Saints Row game was nothing more than a cheap knock off, I liked the 80's metal soundtrack in the game but that was all it had going for it.  The second game is when things got entertaining, they just started to parodize the whole gang thing a lot more and poke fun at some relevant societal topics.  But the third game is when Volition really started to have fun poking fun at how weird the real world was.  Saints Row: The Third wasn't only fun to play but the way it poked fun at the reality tv craze, and Stag was obviously a jab at how Bush handled the war on terror, and it was all done in a very National Lampoon way which was amusing.  Well Saints Row IV, it merely picks up where they left off in three and takes even mroe jabs at a lot of the absurd things in the US, and it pays homage to so many things from the 80's you'll lose count.  There's the level that totally pays homage to They Live and a Christmas Story (briefly), and then there's tons of weapons from 80's classics like Robocop, Aliens, and GI Joe.  And the christmas expansion, the first level is basically a re-creation of the old studio lot where they shot Jaws, Gremlins, and numerous other classics.   But towards the end when it pays homage to the animated Transformers film, and even uses the Stan Bush song from the film, that was just a golden moment in the game.

But I'm praising the satire and how they paid homage to so many great films and cartoons and not talking about the gameplay.  Gameplay wise the game is pretty fun and the super powers the player can use in the viritual world add a whole new level of gameplay to the franchise since in earlier games, the player had to rely on vehicles to get anywhere fast and always rely on guns or grenades, but in the 4th game the player could still go the gun and grenade route or freeze people or turn them into gold or use telekenisis and throw them into the sky.  In short, the game allows players to just go crazy when it comes to taking out pedestrians and the aliens.  The controls are as smooth as the third game, which I'm thankful for since Saints Row 2 for the PC, the driving controls were just horrible.  If one enjoys open world games where they can just go crazy, this game should please them.  But I highly recommend getting the Game of the Century version, or at the very least the base game and the christmas expansion pack.  While I adore Volition's sense of humor when it comes ot the SR franchise, Enter the Dominatrix gets a little too corny, while the Christmas expansion is hands down a far better expansion pack.  I don't recommend playing any of the expansions until after finishing the main game though since the expansions will spoil a few things otherwise.

However, while I think the game is highly entertaining and totally worth dropping 10-20 on, it does have its flaws and they're the same exact flaws the third game had.

1. The game doesn't have the cool drug and booze thing from the second game, I found it highly amusing how the character could get drunk or stoned in the second game and was sad to see them ditch the ability to do that in the third and fourth.  To be fair, it could have been because some countries ban games with drug content, like Australia.

2. The really cool interior locations like the mall in Saints Row 2 added a lot of fun to the game, it was a blast to ♥♥♥♥ off the security guards and then just cause tons of trouble.  But Saints Row 3 and 4 just don't have any of those types of interior locations, which is a shame.

3. The player can still play in the water in three and four but it doesn't take long to notice the water isn't used by any of the npc's like in the 2nd game.  There aren't any npc's jet ski'ing or driving boats or anything like that, the water is just lifeless.

If Saints Row 5 brings back just 1 or 2 of those three things, I'll love it to pieces.

reviewText:
As a huge fan of Saints Row 1 & 2, it's taken me quite awhile to accept the third entry. While that game features improved controls and playability, in terms of everything else it was a step back. Steelport isn't half the city Stilwater was, the atmosphere was sorely lacking, the jokes weren't as funny, and the story & characters weren't nearly as well-written.

Saints Row 4...well, it takes all of SR3's bad qualities and makes them even worse. The idea of having superpowers in an open-world game is always appealing, even though the results rarely satisfy. SR4 grabs elements from a number of these games and doesn't really do anything interesting with them. The Boss runs and jumps across roof-tops to collect orbs, he/she occasionally engages in time-trials, and somethings they just blow a lot of things up. It's the same content that has been done before and better in other games.

What makes a superhero game interesting is when powers lead to new obstacles. Take Prototype for example. The military is always on the lookout for Alex Mercer, and whenever he uses his powers they will bring as much firepower in as possible to bring him down. Despite being able to destroy tanks and helicopters easily, eventually the player is so overwhelmed they have to get away. Limitations are important, they make the player think. Where SR4 fails is that using and abusing powers isn't punished or forces players to get creative. There are occasional missions where no powers are available, but those are just dull. Furthermore the mission design never graduates beyond kill all this stuff" or "protect a thing". In Crackdown the player is tasked with eliminating various crime bosses

reviewText:
Saints Row IV feels like some sort of Matrix mod for Saints Row The Third. It's graphically the same. Even the characters are exactly the same. The last part is a bit obvious of course, since it's a sequel, but still, it would've been nice if they mixed things up. You know, different city, different characters, things like that.

Instead Volition took the easy way out. That doesn't mean Saints Row IV can't be fun, because it can be but I'm sure it will give you that 'been there, done that' feeling, too.

There are plenty of side activities to be done though. It's in no way a small game. It's big, You could play for 25 hours and you still wouldn't have finished it 100%. No, content wise this game is amazing.
It's just that the city isn't worth exploring anymore, especially since you've seen it all in the third game. But it wasn't worth exploring in the first place. There are (almost) no awesome landmarks or anything. It feels like a city but... a regular, simple one. Nothing like the cities of the Grand Theft Auto games, which are epic in scale.

Saints Row IV, for me, is enjoyable and disappointing at the same time.
However, if I had to choose one of those two terms 'disappointing' would be my first choice. Let's hope a possible sequel will give us a better, newer and more fun experience.

[Rating: 72/100]

reviewText:
Saints Row the Third is one of my favorite games ever.  The story was great, the game itself was a hell of a lot of fun, and the replayability is still there.

I was excited for Saints Row IV, but once I got it and played it, I found that I was severely let down.  The whole Matrix vibe is fun for the first little while, but when you realize that because you now essentially have superpowers, you don't even really need to get vehicles or whatnot anymore, that really takes a lot of fun out of the game.  It did for me, anyway.

I found myself not enjoying it at all and uninstalled it to go back to playing SR3.

reviewText:
+ Decently large open-world gameplay
+ Story is absolutely, incredibly ridiculous, in the best possible way
+ Doesn't take itself seriously as a game; focuses on fun and replayability
+ Missions deviate wildly in game type; everything from 2D beat 'em up, racing, old-school DOS choose your path
date:
etc)
+ Massive variety in character, car, weapon, and gang customizations
+ You get ♥♥♥♥ing superpowers
+ Great visuals
+ Tons and tons of game, movie and pop culture references; many of them are quite clever
+ All dialogue is voice-acted; decent quality
+ Side missions are ridiculous and a blast; including mech suit rampages, tank mayhem, telekenesis basketball, and throwing yourself in front of cars for insurance money
+ Funny and clever villain
+ Endless replayability; the game feels like it will never get old

reviewText:
When it comes to Saints Row, this isn't my first rodeo. I played a good amount of SR:TT and loved the game thoroughly. I then decided to pool my funds together and buy this game.

I LOVE IT GOD JUST YES TAKE IT TAKE MY MONEY DLC YOU SAY I'LL TAKE IT ALL

What this game did right:

+ Yippee skippy, super powers! The super powers in this game are fun as hell to use and I like all of 'em a lot. Telekinesis? Sign me up. Super Stomp? Sign me up. The ability to curbstomp any battle easily? Sure.

+ Liked how SR:TT played? You'll feel right at home. Same Steelport, and barring super powers the gun game stays the same, which is satisfying. Driving stayed the same too, so don't worry about sloppy turning on vehicles that didn't have it already.

+ Updated everything. You'll find some pretty nice special effects, a slightly nicer HUD, oh my god a radial wheel for your weapons and an all new suite of weapons and that good ole' Saints Row chatter that's amusing AND mildly psychopathic.

+ A boat of references from the older games. You'll find the DLC costumes from SR:TT in the clothing stores and some older vehicles make a return, you end up resurrecting the tortured existances of your enemies (Like Maero, Tanya and dear Christ Julius is that you) to fight for you like slaves and you even get to fight yourself twice later in the game. Oh whoops spoilers godda-

+ Nolan North is a voice option. NOLAN NORTH. I DON'T THINK YOU UNDERSTAND THE IMPLICATIONS OF THIS SITUATION GET OVER HERE RIGHT NOW SO I CAN TELL YOU HOW GOOD THIS IS TO FINALLY

What this game did wrong:

- No new world. Sure, the Earth kinda sorta got into a pickle what with it being in thousands of molten pieces floating around in space, but at least planetary travel would've been better than Steelport with no Saints in it and always night time.

- Wierd bugs. I don't know about anyone else, but if SR IV bugs up it tends to cry loudly in the corner and throw things at me when I try to ignore it. Like crashing and then trying to restart and doing that in a loop for eternity until I restart Steam. It also freezes up on start if you did something wrong, so unless you can shaft it with certainty it will lock up your computer and make it difficult to close.

- Surprisingly, the super powers. Monster trucks? Alright. New VTOL clones? Sure. Super Sprint and Super Jump? Trumps LITERALLY all of them. Ok, maybe you'll need the VTOL for quick air travel and it helps that you're instantly warped into the vehicle now if you call it in, but the Glide upgrades for the Super Jump make this point null and void. You even shove cars out of the way using Super Sprint, and I don't see any normal Torch or Solar doing that any time soon.

VERDICT:
Saints Row IV is a good game that manages to fit comfortably with me between the so edgy I could cut myself on the box" Saints Row 2 and the "Look at me carrying a big purple floppy dongle while doing a mission drugged and in the nude smacking Europeans in the face with it" Saints Row: The Third. For a game that started out as DLC for SR:TT
date: I would happily take this game over that DLC any day. TL;DR 10/10 buy it right now and experience it for yourself."

reviewText:
10/10 would rectify again.

This game is awesomeness from start to finish. The gameplay is like InFAMOUS with those superpowers, combined with the original sandbox Saints Row formula, it makes for a good combination. I still have not finished the game at the time of this writing, but I'm 8 hours in with 30% game completion, so this game might take a while to beat if you're looking for collectibles and amassing upgrades for your character.

Story is like one of those movies where you fight off aliens, and you're not only the Gang Leader of the Third Street Saints, but also the President of the United States, how awesome is that? The game's story is also expanded through the DLC, adding characters that didn't make the cut in the game. This game also has this Mass Effect-style dialogue system at certain points of the game, but don't quote me on that since I never played Mass Effect. Character development is pretty good, so not all of the characters will come up unestablished, though you'll might have to play the predecessors or read more about the characters to know how they started. Celebrities like Keith David (Foley in MW2, The Arbiter in Halo, Julius Caesar in SR of course) make an appearance in the game.

I'm impressed about how Volition crammed so much content in one package, buying this with the Ultimate Franchise pack is a great deal, shoutout to my bro Andi Rain for hooking me up with a great deal. Coop is awesome and you should definitely have a friend with you to make the game better.

If you're interested, Andi Rain has made some interesting videos on the game, feel free to check them out.
https://www.youtube.com/AndiCRIMSON

reviewText:
Wow I actually made this review long (and I might add to it over time). It might contain some minor spoilers, nothing that'd ruin the experience though I don't think.
This game feels more like a wacky mod for Saints Row 3 than anything, and it's hard to look at it any other way. Let me break this down.

The graphics.
I had to turn those down quite a lot to get the game to run well on my system so I can't judge those, I will mention that a lot of assets (cars, pedestrians...) are the same as in SR3, which I guess could be called lazy but I didn't find them bad looking so why not use them in a newer game.
I appreciate the option to reskin guns, adds some variety. On the other hand the character customisation system seems to have actually become WORSE, with the colour selection even worse than in SR3 and some pieces of clothes causing minor glitches (some tops combined with the Arm Warmers will cause your wrists to float in the air disconnected from your body), plus the selection of clothes is rather limited. Overall customising my character didn't feel nearly as fun as it did in the previous game, partly because 80% of the time my character is glowing cyan so I can't see much of her anyway.

The sound.
The voice acting is alright, sometimes the subtitles don't match what my character is actually saying but it's not the worst. It's a little weird that Female 1 voice reuses a lot of her lines from SR3 but they're re-recorded, not sure why they didn't keep the original lines or come up with new ones, but again, no big deal.
The soundtrack is significantly weaker in my opinion. I do like some songs, but the number was much higher in the previous game.

The gameplay.
Most of the time you have superpowers which basically render every other means of transportation obsolete. I often realised I no longer even perceive that I'm in a city with cars and people, it feels more like a huge sandbox for superjumps, wallruns and other things that may sound like a lot of fun, but basing the whole game around them is just not something I can appreciate. I liked how SR3 felt like an action movie, whereas SR4 feels more like a shoddy Spiderman spinoff movie of sorts. Didn't hit home with me.
The game has a ton of minigames in the form of activities or certain missions, often thrusting you into an alternative reality where your superpowers don't work and you're often forced to use terrible guns, not to mention things like restoring health work differently in the different dimensions. It gets confusing at times.
Some activities are nipple-twistingly boring and/or annoying and/or difficult while some are insultingly easy.
Every chase in the simulation builds up to a miniboss fight which as soon as you've got some upgrades means this: dragonball the thing, shoot it twice, jump into its belly and engage in some keyboard smashing QTE hogwash. Sometimes the pace it requires you to spam keys at is physically impossible to achieve unless you suffer from a rare type of controllable convulsions so you have to do it several times before it works. Who thought this was fun?

The story.
It's a blatant Matrix ripoff. I guess we call that paying homage" these days but really
date: it's a Matrix ripoff. The main storyline was just a little too short and straightforward for my taste (and full of plotholes
hoursPlayed: even the premise itself is fundamentally flawed
voteText: but let's just go with it). The humour feels a lot more tryhard and tongue-in-cheek than in the previous game
helpfulPercent: but it's not unbearable.\nMost of the side missions are just sets of several activities to do
votesHelpful: so if you want to finish all the missions
votesTotal: that means doing 100% city takeover gameplay. Which you probably have to do anyway to have the upgrades necessary to even survive the main missions
votesFunny: which can get difficult at times. Most of the game just feels like a grindfest. A grindfest I'm really not too keen on going through again
commentsCount:
so consider that a thumbs down for replay value.

The conclusion.
I'd say SRIV is inferior to its prequel in nearly every way

reviewText:
Note: I got paid to write for reviews4views website.
Saints Row IV is more insane,looney, and absurd than its last installment from the weapons, super powers,vertical exploration and story. The Saints are the only ones left of the human race to stop their species from being completely annihilated. Being divided and separated as prisoners of multiple alien ships you as the leader are tasked on bringing them back together for the final confrontation.

Progression
+Multiple parts to a quest (better integration with narrative)
+Switch between real life and simulation missions
-Main missions can get repetitive

There is multiple times where you will wake up from the simulation in order to do main missions that are important in order to confront the alien leader. The missions somewhat repeat since you are ultimately saving crew members over and over, but they tend to change up the narrative and the weapons available when doing so.

Quests can have multiple parts to them, depending on how the scenario develops, which flows better with the narrative. Making quests integrated better with the narrative was one of the main goals of the company since the third saints row game.

Side-Missions
+Great variety of rewards (weapons)

The side missions offer a great variety of rewards from beating the objectives. Generally to get the rewards you will have to talk to your crew once you complete the list of quests they have for you. Not all rewards need to be claimed through the crew in order to obtain them especially the ones you get through stimulated instructions and customization quests.

The variety of gameplay is still strong here and very much like the last saints row, except a bit more geared towards superpowers in this installment. Each power has its own challenges you can find throughout the city whether its racing super fast paced checkpoints or using your telekinesis to throw people,cars, and objects through flashy points in a race against the clock.

Simulation - World Design
+Vertical Exploration
-Same steelport as Saints Row 3

Locating them is the hard part - the simulation which is the main component of the game and where the free roam is at. It’s basically the map of steelport with some aesthetic changes, if you were looking forward to a brand new environment then you will be sorely disappointed. The only thing really added to steelport was more vertical exploration (aka) the actual beacon towers you can climb up and activate.

Free Roam
+Super powers make exploration feel fresh
-Vehicles and their customization becomes pointless

Free roam feels different in this game due to the super powers you gain. The super speed and ability to jump high really make traveling feel completely different and somewhat fun. This however ruins the point of traveling with vehicles and makes them nothing but background decoration and weapons to use in confrontations with their occasional use in side missions. Unfortunately making the vehicle customization pointless to even bother with besides gaining respect that’s not really worth the time investment into it.

Super Powers
+Powers offer new ways to combat enemies
+Elements are ways to change outcome of powers

The superpowers take a bit of exploration in order to really build up power in them since you are required to get the data packets scattered around the city. Don’t worry though by no means are they hard to find you can even do a mission that gives you the location of all of them on the mini-map. The superpowers have a decent amount of customization you can do to each power.
The elements change the outcome of powers, which results in 16 possible combinations of different abilities. For example adding explosion element to stomp will allow you to make huge area of effect chain explosions occur. Putting mind manipulation on your powers will also you to bend enemies to your will.

Gear
The weapons like the previous game have a great variety and come in all sorts of looney fun. Especially the weapons in the special category that are around 12 of those. The weapons have two ammo types, being cooldown and reload. This is especially good for players who normally deplete alot of their ammo since they can switch to a cooldown weapon that they don’t have ammo capacity for, or they can simply upgrade the capacity for weapons they do hold it.

Customization
+Vehicle Customization
+Homie Customization

Vehicles can still be customized from increasing durability, turning, and speed attributes to the paint job with body rigging. The cars are saved in your garage once you are done with your customization job, though it would be nice to be able to re-organize the list of vehicles in your garage. You can get rid of vehicles from the garage and keep solely the ones you want but there is no seeming way to actually change the order.

Collectibles
+Good variety (Drug Package, Money Pallet, Sex Doll, Photo Op)

There are 80 collectibles scattered throughout the city, in which appear as random events you can participate in or collect. They are a great way to earn some cash in-between missions while you are free roaming. Though the only reward collecting them all is the 10% increase in game completion for the save.

Phone
+Ability to call backup (vehicles,homies)
+Collecting money simplified

The ability to call backup is very helpful when you are in dangerous situations. Especially useful since it pauses the game essentially for you to start the call, not dieing when navigating menus is always a nice thing afterall. You can recruit up to 3 homies to help you at once, but once you hit the max it will not allow you to attempt to recruit anymore at the time. You also need to run to your homie to revive him so he can continue to help the homies.

Collecting money has been simplified to the point where you just need to open your phone and click on the icon to retrieve your earnings from all the places you tookover. Not having to go to a business or crib to collect money is a real welcome change.

Conclusion
Saints Row IV is a pretty good game despite its flaws and drawbacks as a result for reusing not only the same city but introducing super powers that undercut the fun of customizing vehicles and trying to steal awesome looking sports cars from pedestrians.

reviewText:
Don't bother. Saints Row 3 was an absolute masterpiece. My advice is to buy everything for SR3, play through it twice and if you're still aching for more, then go ahead and pick up 4. This game was supposed to be a DLC for the previous game, but the company who made it went under and this was marketed as a full sequel... Only it isn't. It's a hackney'd moneygrab that chared full retail for something that should have been released for $15.

If you can get this and all of it's DLC crap for $10 or less, then I say go for it. Otherwise, just wait a few more months and get it for what it's worth.

If you haven't played Saint's Row 3, then by all means buy that instead. It's one of the best game experiences I've had in over a decade and it's a shame that it's greatness will likely never be repeated. Saint's Row 4 is a mere shadow of that.

reviewText:
Rating: 9/10

What is it?
Open World gameplay with superpowers


The Good:

+ In an industry that tries so hard to make sure its AAA games have deep mature storylines, (and sometimes failing at that), it is a bit refreshing to play a game that goes in a completely different direction. This game is so over the top and throws just about every crazy idea out there to entertain you, and it all comes together and works.

+ Given the nature of the game with its over the top antics, the writing is surprising excellent. On more than one occasion I was laughing at how witty the dialogue was and the different scenarios that game puts you in.

+ The main missions are well thought and varied. In addition the loyalty missions you can accomplish for your crew mates are equally refreshing and varied.

+ Lots of different activities to do in the game. From causing mayhem, to platform jumping to racing, the game has no shortages of things to do.

+ Lots of collectables that are easy to find that upgrade  your superpowers to be even more powerful. There are plenty of things to upgrade your character, so that by the time you are finished with the game you are practically a walking death tank.

+ Insane amount of customization for your character.

+ Superpowers are really fun to use.

+ Graphics are beautiful.

+ Roddy Roddy Piper

+Cheesy music that just adds to certain scenes making it more memorable

+ Creative DLC

The Bad:

- If you played Saints Row 3 then the city should be familiar to you because its exactly the same.  I think its a bit cheap when a sequel to an open world game uses the exact same layout as the previous game.

- The 'side quests' in this game is nothing more than standard activities you can do throughout the world. The only good thing is that you can complete these activities before a NPC gives it to you.

- I experienced a few bugs and glitches.  It didn't ruin the overall experience but they were noticeable.

- Some of the achievements will require some grinding.

- DLC although creative, was a bit on the short side.


Conclusion:

A game thats all about having fun at your own pace. If you loved saints row 3 you will probably have fun with this.
voteText: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
At its best, Saints Row IV is a love letter to the franchise. At its worst, the game is just a copy and paste of Saints Row The Third with aliens and superpowers.

Superpowers! Blast, Telekinesis, Stomp (each with varying elements like Freeze or Fire), Super Jump, Super Sprint (previewed in SR3 The Trouble With Clones DLC) and several more form the core of the game play, and are the primary attraction. Why take a car when you can run faster than a car? Is that building in your way? Jump over it. Too tall to jump over it? Not to worry: you can wall-run! Need to take out that group of enemies? Sure, you can use guns; but why not drop into the middle of them and stomp your foot once to send them flying? Much easier! The catch is that the superpowers do make the game generally easy (the Superhero Fight Club activities being the frustrating exception).

The story of Saints Row IV is, of course, completely over-the-top. But that's not out of place in a Saints Row game. Rescuing members of your crew requires visiting a simulation of that homie's worst nightmare. There are some fantastic nostalgia trips (you even revisit some of the original Saints Row game) and funny satire (no game or movie is exempt, not even Metal Gear or Mass Effect). Much of it is accompanied by a great selection of songs; shooting up a Genki challenge with a certain character (long thought dead) while “The Boys are Back” was hilarious. While not every character from the franchise appears, all the major ones do.

The downside is that Saints Row IV is, at its heart, a copy-and-paste of Saints Row The Third. Steelport is virtually unchanged; the city map is exactly the same. Activities are exactly the same; Tank Mayhem, for instance, is the same activity with an alien Zin tank instead of an Abrams tank. The planes and aerial vehicles are reskinned SR3 models; they fly and function exactly the same. Hijacking cars is even still a thing; the in-game explanation makes sense, but doesn't hide anything else. With superpowers, cars are a waste anyway. Weapons are unique and fun; but if you've played Red Faction: Armageddon, more than a few will be familiar (Volition developed both games). There's a lot more, but you get the idea.

If you're looking for originality and uniqueness, you won't find it Saints Row IV (outside of the superpower implementation, which is superb). If you're looking for a game that is simply a blast to play – one that will make you laugh far more than it will make you scream in frustration – then absolutely get this game. In a time when all forms of entertainment are getting more serious, the absurdity of Saints Row IV is an absolute breath of fresh air.

On DLC:
As with so many games today, there is too much DLC. At least the Game of the Century Edition includes everything.

reviewText:
Saints Row IV from Volition does what SR series has always delivered in the series - lot of laughs + fun. As if Saints Row: The Third (SR:TT or SR3) didn't ramp up the over-the-top nature of the series, SR4 takes it to another level on the absurdity, ridiculousness, insanity, humor, parodies, jokes, punchlines, crassness, wittiness + fun. SR4 tries to out-do it in numerous ways - and in many ways, SR4 succeeds in doing just exactly that.

After the crazy events from SR3, The Leader of The Saints has now become The President Of The United States. After this + putting Keith David (who plays himself!) in the Cabinet, an alien named Zinyak (who is fantastic + often hilarious, I might add) invades Earth + enslaves everybody into a Simulation World similar to The Matrix. To break free of this, The Saints are on a ship (which reminds me of the Normandy from Mass Effect series) and they try to fight the battle in both the Simulation + Real World to free themselves from this insanity. As if SR3 wasn't ridiculous enough, this here takes things here in SR4 to another level. With also tons of references to events, characters + whatnot from previous SR games - this game also is a Love Letter from Volition that written is directly to their fans that have stuck with them since its inception.

For SR4, you can forget what you know from SR3 about gameplay. This isn't as much of a GTA-style 3rd-person action game where you do most of your moving around the gameworld by driving vehicles - especially when you're in the simulation-world. While you can still do those things in the simulation world + in the real world"

reviewText:
I love this game and it could have been my 2013 GOTY. My favorite parts of the game are the characters, story, the fun of blowing ♥♥♥♥ up, and the amusing weapons. I'm talking to you Singularity Gun and Dubstep Gun. Other than that...

The game feels recycled 70% of the time because you'll be running around the same city of Steelport and doing the same activities with super power twists. The super powers are both good and bad. It's good because you get to wreck stuff like you're Superman, and be able to run around the city like you never could in SR3. It's bad because it made certain mechanics pointless. Why would I even bother driving a car or drive a jet? I can run faster and jump higher. Why do I need to call my homies? I can blow everything away with my fire blast. Enemy AI is still stupid and the 'new' enemies are just reskins from SR3. Character wardrobes feature is fairly limited. Old clothes and tattoos return, but there are only few new ones. It feels like a rip-off they locked away some of the costumes as paid DLCs.

Saints Row 4 is an over-glorified expansion pack for Saints Row the Third. Aside from its funny story, great characters, and fun factor, as a whole, the game is not worth buying at full price. It's a great game for 20 dollars and despite what I said in the second paragraph, the game is still good and very fun to play. I had a blast and I'm sure you'll love it too.

reviewText: Saints Row 4 has got to be one of the best games ive ever played on Steam. Its an open world game where u play as the president of 'Merica. An alien race known as the Zin invade Earth and eventually blow up Earth killing 7 billion people and you and ur crew of 5-10 must go to a simulation of Steelport and apparently isthe only way to kill the leader, Zinyak.\nThere are tons of stuff to do in this game. Its kinda like Skyrim but its set in the modern times. As you make progress in a Simlated City, you will get super powers like jumping higher than Mario and running faster than Sonic. You can also gain powers like shooting a blast of ice, fire, farts and money. Steelport is a huge world as there are certain objectives like take control of Hotspots, Flashpoints and Towers which affect Zin and other enemies. There are also store that must be hacked before purchasing whatever they have. There are stores like Tatoos, Guns & ammo, Clothes and Garages. There is also something called Data Clusters scattered literally everywhere you see. These Data Clusters are used to upgrade your Super Powers. Speaking of Upgrading, you can upgrade yourself like Weapons, Health, even your Gang like their health and weapons. There are even i guess you can call them mini-games since you have a time limit to get a certain amount of cache (not cash). Like big games like Grand Theft Auto V and Skyrim, Saints Row 4 is a glitchy game which is no suprise.\nI give this game 9 out of 10 because there is a lof of buildings but yet you cant even enter many of them. I like the graphics are and the gameplay. I just love games that you can upgrade yourself, seriously.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I binged through this game in about 5 days' time because of sleeping troubles. Some of the following may not apply if you play this at a sane rate.

A huge amount of how you feel about SR4 is probably going to relate to how you felt about SR3, because not-really-a-spoiler: your open world is 99% Steelport again. (There are minor changes.) Even being given extra time after the implosion of former publisher THQ, this game was clearly originally an expansion, and some parts of it really show that corner-cutting when you play through it. On the plus side, though - some of the reuse is done in actual clever ways, and this is where I come to my huge divide about the game: the gameplay gets really, really tired at times, but the writing is pretty sharp.

This game was a pretty clear sendoff/love letter to the franchise, going as far back as SR1 and a whole lot of nods to the earlier titles the further you go along. In fact, probably the entire back half of the game* is winking fanservice to SR1/2 and the stuff that 3 dropped a lot of. Let me point out: none of it is what I'd call half-♥♥♥♥♥"
date: either. They seriously got the original VAs from these games to replay their roles
hoursPlayed: and added optional content to the point of letting you recruit some deep cut characters. Or
voteText: if you buy the "complete" edition with DLCs - just plain cut characters.\n\nI could go on and make a huge list of the ups and downs of this
helpfulPercent: but basically
votesHelpful: do you want to run around a virtual world as a superpowered god
votesTotal: causing mayhem and comedy in your wake? That's this game. It's a superpowered ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ simulator and it doesn't pretend to be anything else.\n\nI will give one handy tip

reviewText:
This game gets so much more hate than it deserves, It is quite possibly one of, if not, the best open world sandbox game ever made. People complain about it not being DLC to saints row 3, If this was DLC to saints row 3, it would have to be one of the biggest DLC's to any game I've ever seen, Let's just take a look at all the new features to this game.

New Weapons, New Characters, More New types of enemies than in the previous games, 65 Power Upgrades, Multiple new Homies, More Body Customization, More Weapon Upgrades, 111 Weapon Skins, More Vehicals, More Vehical Customization, 1600 Collectiables, New Activities, Brings back Johnny Gat, Brings Back SR2 Shaundi, Has Keith David voice both himself and Julius, Has the upgrade system from Saints Row 2 and it Takes you back to Stillwater to please older fans.

People who complain about this basically being a saints row 3 DLC or that it's nothing much more than Saints row 3 are just wrong, plain and simple.

Storywise, Yes it's a ♥♥♥♥ take right from the very start. And I can understand people feeling like this was a bad way to continue on from the last few games. However, I'm a huge fan myself of games that involve alot of comedic relief so I didn't find anything wrong with it personally. As a saints row story, It's not dedicated to the last few games, But as a standalone game, the story is amazing, hilarious, intense and just downright insane. You don't see that in many triple A games nowadays so this definately pleased me.

The Replayability is Great as always with the Saints Row Games, I've just completed my second playthrough and am currently working through a third one.

Another issue people found with this game is that Cars are pointless because you now have super powers. My thoughts on this are, At the start of the game, you don't have access to many super power upgrades and to even buy them, you have to slowly collect clusters one by one to then purchase them. You also have the option to purchase unlimited Nitro boost for vehicals and with the added extra vehical customization I mentioned earlier, Driving cars is still alot of fun in this game and I still use them quite a bit during my gameplay.

I'm just rambling on here so I'll finish this up. This game has its flaws, but they are highly overshadowed by the amazing expirience of the game itself. Without a doubt or any second thought, This is my Top game of 2013.

10/10

reviewText:
Back when I was playing Saints Row 1, I had hoped the series would become more than just a GTA clone. It did. Some people got really upset that it changed its overall tone from violent, somewhat dark gangster/crime stories to a very loony and lighthearted tale, but I personally believe that it was for the better.

Saints Row has become something very different. The weirdness is cranked so far that the knob is now broken, yet this Saints Row has the most character development I've ever seen in the series. The game makes callbacks to previous titles, and isn't afraid to give more depth to the characters' motivations and their concerns.

Gameplay wise, it's fun but it gets tired after you unlock enough powers and abilities to make any gunfight a cinch. Thankfully, the characters and dialogue are interesting enough to keep things going. If you like serious games, this isn't for you. If you like crazy, hilarious fun, this is most likely up your alley.
