reviewText:
*single tear* Ah, another game genre comes to debunk my bias. A sandbox with a delinquent hero on my command.
Just like with FPS and generally games with lots of violence, Saints Row much like Grand Theft Auto didn't appeal to my eye, until I was offered me the fourth installment of the series as a gift. And oh boy, wasn't it a pleasant surprise.
I love to blow stuff up, and I sure as hell love to do it to those who want to claim Earth, so this was the first step. Slowly but steady, the stunning character renders just won me with their realistic expressions, their lines always keeping me entertained, and it doesn't end there. I'll try to keep this short, I promise.

Excellent story concept? Check. Doesn't matter if it's far-fetched and not one with the real world, it still makes sense as a concept.

Satisfying combat action? Check. Causing mayhem is a piece of cake and with a plethora of weapons and upgrades, beating enemies up is never a tedious task in this game. I'd say the mayhem trigger system is the same as Jak II, yet the combat here is way easier, but I should probably not carry on with comparing the game. I did see Jason Rubin somewhere around the credits though... ;P
Oh, and the vehicles were all really cool. While not being a fan of them in general, the ones in the game were so fun to drive. Oh how I love to perform stunts while driving like a lunatic in a simulation, haha.

Stunning graphics and awesome characters? Damn yeah check. Ascending from a street gang leader to the President of a country sounds so unreal that ends up sounding awesome. In a video game, that is. But the concoction of this category's elements was clearly too delicious for words. How could I not love playing as the supposed President of the USA who pretty much looks like an Australian hippie? Haha, but seriously, Obama, Bush, Clinton, and those before them, I wonder if they ever had to go through similar tasks?
The voice acting was flawless as well, my jaw dropped as I witnessed the credits! Let's not forget the references, MGS, various internetic memes, oldschool game tokens and easter eggs and so many more which were a real source of humour for the whole game.
Virtual Steelport looks lovely too, and with all the glitches it's just plain hilarious. As one progresses into the game and crushes the simulated world, it all gets so much more interesting. The character uniforms are eye-candy too, just look at all that purple and the fleur-de-lis badge. Makes me appreciate purple as a colour, really.

Kickass music? Epicly huge CHECK! Not only was the game's soundtrack itself spot-on, but the radio song choices were also ever so upbeat and cheerful! I discovered many new songs to smash the replay button for, as well as have fun in town in my own way. Even my DJ-wannabe self came back to life temporarily. XD

Look at me saying I'll keep this short. Oh well...
tldr, THIS, WAS, AWESOME! So many good feelings, so many good thoughts, I just feel like I had one of the best parties in my life after finishing this game. I had fun in every single second of it. If you're into this kind of games, you've already got this game and most likely beat it since it's nearly 2 years since it came out too lol. If you're not, then I still recommend it to you, since it's still a beautiful experience. The Saints Row franchise has earned another eager fan.

And by the way, if you're reading this Edo, you're a ♥♥♥♥ing awesome friend, and thanks for giving me this game. Can't wait to blow ♥♥♥♥ up with you again. Like the President did with his old bud Johnny Gat. Also thanks for bugging me all winter long to do so in the first place.

reviewText:
Just to make things clear, I want to point out that I wasn’t a huge fun of Saint’s Row The Third, even more so, I hated it. I didn’t liked what Volition did with Saint’s Row franchise. Even though i didn’t like previous installment of SR, I have decided to pick up this game and review it.

I wasn’t expecting gangster-type Saint’s Row when I bought this but I had a big expectations from this game and I have got to say I wasn’t disappointed. Firstly, you start the game as a president of the United States which is a clever idea and it got me thinking, what are they going to come up with next year, will you be playing as God? anyway let’s get to the point. You start the game as a president and of course Aliens invaded the Earth and then destroyed it, yes, you read this well, Aliens have destroyed our planet, just like that. Only some gang members have survived including, Pierce, Shaundi, Johny Gat and others, so now it is your mission to get out of the simulation and defeat Zinyak( Leader of the Aliens).

For some reason Zinyak, doesn’t want to kill you, in fact he transforms you into this simulation(clear spoof of Matrix) and what is funny is the fact that he allows you to have superpowers and i have got to say superpowers are the most fun thing to have in the game. Instead of travelling by car you can just run around or fly around which is extremely convenient and fun but there are also some problems that I have with them. If you have ability to fly and super sprint through the town you won’t be using cars, AT ALL which is a shame because the developers have improved vehicle customization and with your superpowers these improved aspects of customization are useless.


Let’s get to the story, I actually really liked it. It was funny, full of sexual jokes and some great references from the other Saint’s Row games. Even at one point you get to visit Stillwater and fight some bosses from previous games. Although I did had some problems with side missions, some of them were ok, especially the Super Homie missions, but others were repetitive, ”go to point a, fight some aliens and then go to point B” type of missions but I had to complete them because I really wanted to get my hands on Dubstep Gun, Black Hole Gun and other really hilarious ones. As for the story, I don’t want to spoil anything but I really hated the last boss fight with Zinyak. It was cheap and frustrating, I expected something more… fun I might say but overall the story was hilarious.

Furthermore, I did had some fun playing minigames although some of them weren’t as good as other. In my opinion the best minigames are Insurance Fraud(of course) and Mech Mayhem. Text Adventures were fun as well. Other minigames were…well…acceptable.

Lastly, Saint’s Row 4 offers us a decent but hilarious story, good character customization and of course superpowers. You will definitely have a lot of fun with this game especially if you could convince your friend to play it with you. But I’m a bit sad that the car customization is pretty much useless just because your superpowers, It would be better if the developers gave you the superpowers after you finish the game or after 50% completion, but this is just my opinion. Besides, If you didn’t liked the previous Saint’s Row, you should really give it a try and If you are a huge fan of Saint’s Row 1 and 2, you might be a bit disappointed by the lack of seriousness.

reviewText:
A very fun and unusual game.

Saints Row IV incorporates the best features from SR3 but also enhances many of the most lacking elements of it's predecessor.  It does appear however that the game engine and graphics had changed very little or not at all, which may disappoint those wanting a significant upgrade to the visuals.  The game does look decent on the PC but does seem to be a bit behind other recent titles.

I did not think that Volition would be able to go even more over the top" than they did with SR3
date: but they somehow managed to do so
recommended: and in a way that fits the game very well.  At no point did it seem that the humor in the story was forced or placed for the sake being there.\n\nThe campaign is very well scripted and dialoged.  I did particularly like the banter between the various members of the Saints.  The game has a great antagonist in the alien overload Zinyak who has a witty English accent and a very Bond-esque villain personality.  The game also finds a lot of ways to include throwbacks to the previous titles in the series
hoursPlayed: which should please those who have played those games.\n\nThe main theme behind the game borrows heavily from some favorite Sci-Fi action films like the Matrix (1999) and They Live (1988).  Most of the gameplay is in a very Matrix-like virtual city of Steelport where the player has to free other captured friends and attempt to break out of the simulation via hacking and disrupting.  Much like the Matrix
voteText: you spend a lot of time switching between a real-life ship and the virtual city of Steelport
helpfulPercent: and super powers are learned in the virtual world as the player learns more about how to master and disrupt the virtual environment.  There is a TON of missions and side activities to keep the player busy and many of the familiar side activities from SR3 make a comeback with some fun twists (though Snatch and Escort missions are omitted this time
votesHelpful: YAY!)\n\nBiggest complaint I would see is in the super powers that the player gets in the simulated Steelport.  While they are great fun and add a very interesting element to the gameplay
votesTotal: the powers will render the automobiles and many of the weapons obsolete.  The gameplay with superpowers in the open world does greatly resemble that of games like Prototype
votesFunny: Crackdown and inFamous
commentsCount: so the game does feel more like a really good super hero simulator or Matrix game rather than a GTA style crime game.  The player will also find the game not too challenging with upgrade super powers
column16: but the great writing
column17: over-the-top gameplay and humor makes up for the lack of challenge.\n\nOverall the game continues to shamelessly build on the over-the-top gameplay that SR3 did and further distance itself from GTA and earlier Saints Row titles.  The result turned into something rather unique and it seems that Volition has become rather adept at creating a very fun and zany game that does not take itself too seriously.  If you liked the direction that SR3 took with the series then you will probably enjoy this game as much as I did."

reviewText:
Saints Row IV is an open world action game.

Like in the previous games, you play as the leader of the Third-Street Saints. Except this time you are now the President of the United States.

You are abducted by aliens and put into a simulation, which you must escape. In the simulation you gain superpowers. From the ability to jump great distances, to freezing enemies, there is a lot of powers at your disposal. As well as the superpowers, you gain a whole ton of wacky weapons, such as the dubstep gun or anal probe.

The gameplay is a ton of fun, and the ability to play with a friend makes it so much better. There is a huge amount of side missions/activities to keep you busy as you roam around the simulation.

The game originally started out as a DLC for Saints Row the Third. But it feels absolutely nothing like one. The main campaign is around 15-20 hours long, and there is a ton of extra content to keep you busy as you play. The developers stated they scraped most of the original DLC version of the game, to instead make this a full retail release. And it is just like any other. In fact, it provides more content than most $60 titles these days.
People also criticised the fact it uses the same map as SR3. These people are idiots. Don't listen to them. Many games do this, and no one ♥♥♥♥♥es then. It's just another silly reason to write this game off as a DLC.

A possible downside to the game is that superpowers make using vehicles seem a bit pointless, especially late game. But all of that customisation is there for those who still wish to use it. Also, with the missions in which you exit the simulation, movement can be a bit of a drag as you run at normal speeds again. Luckily the missions are not very long, and the feeling of being slower wears off quickly.

Overall an amazing game. Possibly my favourite Saints Row. I especially recommend this to people who love 2-player co-op games.

reviewText:
This game has it's ups and downs.
The good side of it is the story, the amount of customization, the graphics and the humour. It's a well put together game that can keep you occupied for hours, even days even you like freeroaming.

the flaws of this game in my opinion is how they've layed the powers out, the speed and jump power in particular. I think they're very over powered and leave you with no reason for using cars since you can go faster than cars and jump really high, getting around the island is far too quick and easy, whats more, without needing to use cars theres not much point in customizing cars. I think the speed and jump system needs to be lowered down and limited alot more, atleast add it to the game further on, because these are the first powers you get so the game gets easy far too quickly and spoils alot of the free roaming adrenaline (if you know what I mean).

having power limitation would be alot more helpful too, I know that things can have a cooldown, which are not that long after upgrading it, but having a power bar (like a mana bar kind of thing) would be nice too, including it to only be restored from killing drops just like health.

overall it's a great game and I would recommend it, I would also recommend playing on a hard difficulty since it's a little too easy and overpowered quite quickly in.

reviewText:
PROS:
+ Funny missions.
+ Quite good radio stations.
+ New wacky weapons.
+ You get all DLC vehicles from The Third for free.
+ New activities.
+ Customization options.
+ Community and achievements.
+ Upgrade system.
+ Good optimization.
+ Awesome superpowers.
+ Clusters (it's fun to collect them).
+ Audio logs and text adventure.
+ Lots of references to previous SR games.
+ Saints of Rage minigame.
+ More easter eggs (though still, much less than in SR2).
+ Less bugs.
+ Quite good mission packs (espessially How the Saints Saved Christmas).
+ Better DLCs overall (even despite another DLC with cheats).
+ Modding.

CONS:
- Messed up storyline.
- It's Steelport again.
- Again, very few things to do in the open world.
- Again, lots of missing characters and unfinished plots (where the hell is Dex?).
- Again, no mission nor cutscene replay.
- Again, small variety of pedestrians and their cowardness.
- Again, pretty weak car damage system.
- Again, there's no way to toggle upgrades.
- No choises.
- No gangs.
- No cribs (except The Ship).
- No commercials in the radio.
- Earth explodes.
- This isn't Saints Row anymore.

I rate it 7,5 out of 10. It's hard to call this Saints Row - it doesn't have anything to do with the series, except characters and references - but I must admit it's an awesome game and it's really fun to play it.

reviewText:
I am a huge fan of the Saints Row Franchise and I know many people would say that the quality of the games has gotten worse and worse with every new release ... but I still can only recommend Saints Row IV.
If you are looking for a game where you can turn your brain off and just feel absolutely powerful by doing pretty much anything you want, then this is the game for you. The game is plain ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, but it's never been meant to be taken seriously. It's a game to have fun with, mess around and just enjoy yourself.
There's a lot that has been taken over from the third installment, but even those activities are being modified so you won't feel bored. There's a ton to collect, a huge amount of side missions and just the references that are layed out throughout the game to other games are hilarious.

My recommendation: If you have a sense of humour and just want to mess around, buy it. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
An openworld sandbox game that is quite ridiculous and completely humorous, If you havn't picked up this game yet please do so now and get this great game.


The intro game starts off with the BOSS of saints row going after Cyrus the leader of stag. You'll kill him but you won't be able to stop him from launching a nuke at washington. Boss climbs on top of the nuke and does what he does best. The game then goes forward to the future where the BOSS is now president of the United States.  As the crew makes it to the White Crib, an alien invasion hits the boss and captures everyone. Then they are proceeded to be put into a simulator where the game begins and all hell breaks loose.

The gameplay is not just like any other third person shooter in the series but since the game takes place in a simulation all hell breaks loose. You will not only run around in this openworld sandbox game but you'll gain superhuman abilities to fight the aliens. You'll get reminded of prototype with these sort of powers such as glyding or leaping at buildings and using guns out of all sorts. One favorite is the dubstep gun or the shrink ray. There are so many new variety of weapons to choose from. Aside from that there are scattered quests and objectives you can do to level up yourself. You can do alot of customization on your character and steal and ride cars but lets face it. Cars are useless when you have power.


The game didn't revolutionize anything in the openworld sandbox genre nor did it level the game's graphic by updating the engine. Cars are useless in the beginning and some of the quests sets could be done better. The outrageous badly written story that is funny, really well picked music, and the hilarious jokes involved in this game makes up for it. The game is downright fun and the weapons are fun as well. With the sale and all dlcs this is a must have title if you want to kill some time with shennenigans

reviewText:
Saints bless the universe!  Finally, it's here!  The game I've been waiting for ever since I didn't like the Matrix games!  Saints Row IV takes you on an epic journey from President to alien slave to superhero!

Saints Row IV is a violent good time.  While I have not played coop mode, single-player mode is awesome.  I like the super powers a lot.  The first two are exactly like the movement powers you may have seen in the Prototype games, super speed and high jumps.  Later powers get more combat oriented, and most of the upgrades are useful.

There are a lot of hilarious antics going on around you, and the music is sometimes enough to make you laugh.  Think South Park style humor then Matrix style fight-the-man resistance (starring you, the former The Man") with a bunch of other crazy little aspects.

There are some glitches.  You can get stuck very easily early in the game if you jump on some simple boxes.  It upset me a lot because it meant I had to replay the most boring part of the game: the intro.  That said
date: if you try not to jump around too much there
recommended: the later levels let you jump as much as you like.  Also
hoursPlayed: I experienced some friendly AI characters going crazy and trying to kill me... no real explanation.  I guess that's alright. Just more cannon fodder for my plasma pistol.\n\nOverall
voteText: I give this game a solid 5/5.  It's as fun as a game could be.  It doesn't take things seriously
helpfulPercent: but it gives you enough story to care about what you're trying to accomplish.  It had great visuals
votesHelpful: that SR3 art style we all love

reviewText:
Heh, after almost 30 hours of gameplay time i can honestly say that saints row 4 is a game u dont wanna let out of your hands... ever... One of the few things that makes me want to play these game series is the excellent style and innovation u see every time u pick a new game. Number 1 and 2 had excellent storytelling and more awesome graphics than its current gta franchise titles. Saints row the third went beyond that and brought surreal fun into the gameplay while still maintaining the aforementioned qualities. And now saints row 4 did it again with the current installment only this time its even better than before!!!


I can go on and on about the game and what it offers, but it all sums up into two words: super powers! If y ever wanted to feel what it is like to be superman, this game comes as close to it as any. Super strength, speed, flying, stomping, telekinisis, freezing/fire beams, everything u can think off can be found in this title. Even if u dont like open sandbox worlds this is one game that will change your whole perspective in the genre. Hell u are so powerful u can nuke punch a part of the city.
And if u arent into super powers dont worry this game is still for u. Alien weapons, awesome new spectacular and flashy vehicles, even more surreal weapons (dubstep gun and blackhole gun!!!!!!!!!), super powered homies and i saved the best two for last: mecha power armor suit to blast your way through every situation and Rody ♥♥♥♥ing Piper as a homie!!!!


Saints row 4 is for me at least one of the best games out there. It takes  what the series is about - fun in game that is - and blasts it into a whole new lvl.  The only fault in this game is the kinds short main story due to the fact the game was originally built as an expansion to the saints row the third. Other than that is a perfect title to play and own. When u are bored with it, its only cause saints row 5 is on the horizon!

reviewText:
Heh, after almost 30 hours of gameplay time i can honestly say that saints row 4 is a game u dont wanna let out of your hands... ever... One of the few things that makes me want to play these game series is the excellent style and innovation u see every time u pick a new game. Number 1 and 2 had excellent storytelling and more awesome graphics than its current gta franchise titles. Saints row the third went beyond that and brought surreal fun into the gameplay while still maintaining the aforementioned qualities. And now saints row 4 did it again with the current installment only this time its even better than before!!!


I can go on and on about the game and what it offers, but it all sums up into two words: super powers! If y ever wanted to feel what it is like to be superman, this game comes as close to it as any. Super strength, speed, flying, stomping, telekinisis, freezing/fire beams, everything u can think off can be found in this title. Even if u dont like open sandbox worlds this is one game that will change your whole perspective in the genre. Hell u are so powerful u can nuke punch a part of the city.
And if u arent into super powers dont worry this game is still for u. Alien weapons, awesome new spectacular and flashy vehicles, even more surreal weapons (dubstep gun and blackhole gun!!!!!!!!!), super powered homies and i saved the best two for last: mecha power armor suit to blast your way through every situation and Rody ♥♥♥♥ing Piper as a homie!!!!


Saints row 4 is for me at least one of the best games out there. It takes  what the series is about - fun in game that is - and blasts it into a whole new lvl.  The only fault in this game is the kinds short main story due to the fact the game was originally built as an expansion to the saints row the third. Other than that is a perfect title to play and own. When u are bored with it, its only cause saints row 5 is on the horizon!

reviewText:
After playing Saints Row IV for just over fifteen hours, beating the campaign, and enjoying a few side missions along the way, I have noticed vast improvements throughout the series.

Customization:
As most of you should know, customization is key in games such as Saints Row, Grand Theft Auto, and other sandbox games along these lines. Games in the Saints Row franchise have all had some sort of deep customization. Players can create exact replicas of themselves, or even turn into whatever they desire. Although in this addition to the series, we are not left disappointed. The possibilities are endless. Would you like to go around shooting people with Dual Wielded SMGs? You can do that!  Want to shoot up a store with Han Solo's signature blaster? You can do that too! Whatever you sick little mind can come up with; you can do it.

Gameplay:
Looking back at Saints Row: The Third, you'll definitely notice how many of the activities have reappeared. Some of your favorites such as Tank Mayhem and Insurance Fraud. Although, in this addition to the franchise, the activities have gotten far more challenging; giving the player a harder time and not making the game drift away so quickly. For example, when you're ragdolling your character around the city in Insurance Fraud, you'll need to gain a certain amount of money to either earn Bronze, Silver, or Gold!

City Upgrades:
If you've played any of the other Saints Row games, you've probably noticed the lack of aerial combat. That has changed completely in Saints Row IV. When the developers added the VTOL hover-jets and rocket cycles, it just makes the game feel that much more entertaining. We've also seen improvements on the vertical areas of Stilwater, it's far easier to throw yourself off the top of a building to a quick and easy death. That is, only if you don't have your superpowers activated ;)

Removal of Importance:
Remember in the previous Saints Row games when you had to earn respect" from your crew and gang? They've removed that and simply changed it's name to XP. While this makes sense due to the scenerios and there only being about nine humans technically alive. It still makes the game feel a little less like the classic "Saints Row" style game.

Cars and Music:
Basically since this game takes place almost entirely inside a computer simulation
date: you can do some pretty awesome things. One of them being that you can hijack a car and then "upload" it into your virtual garage. Later on
recommended: you can simply "download" it to wherever you may be on the map. It's pretty much the same as the cars
hoursPlayed: but now you can play music wherever you may be. Yes
voteText: you read that correctly. You don't even need to be in a car! This adds a whole new level of excitement to the game
helpfulPercent:
and makes it much more enjoyable.

Overall:
Overall
votesHelpful: this game was fun to play through and gave me plenty of time driving around and killing ferocious aliens. Although it kind of seems like a let down
votesTotal: it feels just like a large expansion to Saints Row: The Third. I still recommend it
votesFunny: as it has a unique story and will give you many laughs along the way!"

reviewText: Saints Row 4 is the game I wanted to exist in 1999 but wasn't delivered for another 15 years. I can only compare it to its predecessors, and it seems a direct mating between Saints Row, the franchise (perhaps as popularized by the seminal Saints Row 2) and The Incredible Hulk: Ultimate Destruction. Hulk introduced the building-traversing superhero powers that are central to this game, and also later appeared in the soon-to-be-forgotten Prototype franchise. The abilities granted in this game also later appeared in Crackdown, but the genesis seems to be Hulk: Ultimate Destruction. It's the first instance I can recall of building-scaling superhero powers melded with a free-roam GTA premise. This game capitalizes on the dreams of GTA3 and that era of exploration in gamespace and intentionally places itself in the context of that era with its soundtrack, customization options and game types. If you watched The Matrix in 1999 and thought HOLY ♥♥♥♥ this would be an awesome video game, here it is.\n\nIt reminds me most of a Quake 2 mod from that era called, I THINK, Brazen? It was an Action Quake 2 mod that added in flashy physics like wall-running and superjumps, shortly after The Matrix debuted. Of course, the scale of a Quake 2 map is nothing compared to Steelport. I almost feel like you have to be a certain age to enjoy this game, but that may be my own failing to understand the contextual existence of younger generations.

reviewText:
First Off I am Loving this game.


Yes in a way it is similar to SRTT but there are alot of different things to do in SR4 which makes you forget about that.


The gameplay has been pretty enjoyable, the fact you have all these crazy superowers makes roaming so much more fun. Liike running up building and jumping from rooftop to rooftop.

Then you got the weapons the most iconic gun in the SR4 arsenal to me is the Dubstep Gun :D, its a pretty dam fun gun to use, there is dlc to give you a remixed dubstep gun which you can change the song on it which then always changes how the gun acts.

The Story So far has been awesome, a great ride (still going as i write this) has never been a dull moment in this game even just roaming around collectables and hacking all the shops can be made very very fun ^-^

The DLC content also looks and sounds good, more mission, costumes, clothing, weapons all that good stuff with even more to come!

A must buy even at full price, if you on the fence then just try it at a friends house or whenever they do another free weekend.

reviewText: The Saints Row series is perhaps one of the greatest modern examples of “don’t judge a book by its cover” in video gaming history. The first game was widely written off as a GTA knock-off, and to be fair it mostly was. However, there were hints at greatness even then, from lightning you could summon with your cell phone to a voodoo priest that could revive dead allies as zombies. Having been there since the very beginning, it did my heart good to see the overwhelming positive reaction to The Third, and Volition has struck while the iron is hot with Saints Row IV. The project started as standalone DLC when the company was owned by THQ, and has now morphed into a full retail release. Many have been asking, is this worth the full price point knowing that? Yes. Yes it is.\n\nFull Review located at http://www.geekenstein.com/saints-row-iv-review/

reviewText:
Saints Row IV is a crazy game for crazy people. The major selling point of this sequel is how much it bends the original premise of the series. Some view that as a bad thing. I on the other hand, feel that it's what keeps things fresh.

Smash aliens with a superhuman arsenal of nukes!

Drop the bass with the Dubstep Gun!

Play some Telekinetic Mind over Murder!

There's so much to do!

reviewText: Note: I also previously owned this on console and played a lot of hours and beat the game.\n\nSaints Row IV is the weakest of the Saints Row franchise, but it's not horrible. The story is insane.. and sometimes that's not good. After Saints Row: The Third, it was obvious that Saints Row would not be serious anymore.. and that's fine.. but a lot of stuff in the story just doesn't make sense and can't be looked past. How could someone who has literally murdered 1000's of people (a lot of them innocent) become president? The super powers are the biggest thing for me though. Yes in Saints Row IV you now have super powers.. awesome right? Not really. When you first get powers and start using them, it is in fact pretty awesome.. then it soon wears off and you realize how overpowered you really are. There is also basically NO need for cars.. since you can super speed run faster than them and also you can fly. After the first few hours I literally never used a car again. The game is still fun for screwing around with when you're bored though, but I would only recommend it to people who wanna do that. I'm going to say click recommoned" because I wouldn't not recommend it.. but I'm going to rate it 6.5/10."

reviewText: Mr Anderson
date: welcome back"\n\nThe latest game in the Saints Row series has gone through a lot before we got to play it ourselves. Originally intended as a DLC for Saints Row: The Third
recommended: it was expanded far beyond that
hoursPlayed: and then the original Publishers for the series
voteText: THQ
helpfulPercent: went bust and this was picked up by Deep Silver. This could have been a very different game
votesHelpful: but rather than consider what might have been
votesTotal:
I'm here to let you know what we did get. So on to the review.

Story
The game opens up with a mission where you and your crew need to stop an old enemy from attacking the US with nuclear weapons. Once you have obviously succeeded at this
votesFunny: you then spend several years as the President of the United States before Earth is attacked by aliens. After failing to fight back
commentsCount: you find yourself in the Matrix
column16: and must learn to use this to your advantage so you can stop the alien leader and save the planet. That is all in the first hour
column17: and only gets even crazier as you get further in the game. Its just a little over the top
column18: but they had to outdo the previous game somehow. Saints Row has become all about having a crazy story
column19:
and Volition didn't want to disappoint.

Presentation
In these aspects
column20: the game has changed little from the previous release. Everything still looks pretty much the same
column21: other than a few effects showing off the fact that you spend most of the game in a simulation
column22: such as pixelization of surroundings
column23: and the occasional glitched character (don't worry
column24: they are meant to be messed up). The voice acting is just as good as the previous game as well
column25: with the characters sounding as they did the last time you spent taking on enemies of the Row. Sound effects don't appear to have changed either. All of it makes it obvious that while it might have gone far beyond the original plans
column26: this was going to be a DLC for an older game.\n\nNow
column27: the soundtrack at least has seen some additions
column28: but also the loss of some older stations. The metal of The Blood is no more along with the loss of WDDT and Kabron. It instead has Mad Decent for your rap needs and Four 20 with a mix of reggae and dub. Fortunately
column29: if you share my taste in music and listen to The Mix
column30: you will still be satisfied by the quality of the music even if we can't sing The Final Countdown. Looking at the full selection of songs
column31: it might not be as good as it was in Saints Row 2
column32: but the playlist available in this game is still impressive. A nice little feature they also included is the ability to play music outside of a vehicle. Very happy with that
column33:
as you may not spend much time putting up with wheels.

Controls
Another place where there have been few changes
column34: the controls have gotten away with only a few minor tweaks to take into account the powers you have access to. Grenades have been removed so they had somewhere to map the powers
column35:
and taunts as well as recruiting and dismissing gang members now require you to hold as those keys are also used to toggle your powers. Everything else still works as it did in Saints Row: The Third.

Gameplay
Now
column36: here is where all the changes will be found. To start with
column37: it plays just like Saints Row: The Third. Get a car
column39: etc. But early in the game
column40: you start picking up data clusters and taking down the Wardens of the simulation
column41: allowing you to unlock special abilities. Running around as fast as a car and jumping like Spider-Man
column42: then later then gliding around as if you were that guy in Prototype. Suddenly
column43: you have little reason to even bother with a car. Not only can you cover more ground outside of one
column44: you won't find most of the clusters needed to upgrade your powers without hopping around the rooftops to collect them. This very quickly makes most vehicles a waste of time outside of missions and moving around your useless homies.\n\nWait
column45: did I just call your homies useless? Why
column48: when you move around like a demented grasshopper and can shoot fireballs or make earthquakes
column49: some guy with a pistol won't cut it
column50: and they can't even follow you most of the time. I hate it
column51: but you just won't call them up for help
column52: but only because an achievement will unlock after spending enough time with a few of them. Some of the more important homies will eventually gain their own powers by doing certain side missions
column53: but even they are rarely needed on your various quests.\n\nWhile the changes to the game have made both vehicles and your gang unneeded
column54: the missions themselves continue to be highly enjoyable. From flying through the sky as you chase your current target to giving the smackdown to brutish aliens
column55: the most important part of the game does the job and keeps you busy until you reach the end of the game. You have a significant number of main missions to work on
column56: as well as all the side missions to unlock enhanced homies
column58:
new weapons and even a new costume or two. Getting everything out of the way will take many hours of fun.

Lifespan
Even after completing the main story
column59: there is still enough to do to keep you busy for a while after the credits roll. Each of the takeover activities now has different ranks
column60: allowing you to try for a Gold on each of them. As well as that
column61: you can also work of completing the Challenges
column63: jumping as much as you can
column64: and wiping out hundreds of aliens in as many ways as possible. And even after you have done all of these and gotten a 100% save
column65: you have the option of doing it all with a friend.\n\nAs you can see
column67: though not without a few flaws. Still
column68: it is easily worth a purchase. I can't deny it was money well spent.\n\n8 / 10"

reviewText:
Would recommend but only if it's on sale. Solid, funny writing (parody galore), over the top action as you would expect from a Saints Row game. If you like the humour from last game, you won't be dissapointed. The super power gameplay mechanic plays pretty well but this game feels like it should have been an expansion rather than a full release (hence only buy it when it's on sale). The mechanic is expanded from what they had with 'Trouble with Clones' DLC from Saints Row 3 so if you enjoyed that, you'll definitely like this.

Fairly short game. I fnished all main story, loyalty missions, side missions and all collectibles except for the data clusters (super power upgrade currency) in about 20 hours. Plenty of padding with the side missions which is basically a set of activities. If you are not really a completionist, you can probably blitz through the main story and loyalty missions (worth doing) pretty quickly.

Technical side, no problems or game breaking bug encountered during my playthrough. I think it only crashed once.

reviewText: Field        Rating        Comments                Graphics        8.0        Graphically, this isn't all that much of a step up from the last entry. While they aren't bad by any stretch of the imagination, they leave a little bit to be desired considering it's the same engine, same city, and mostly the same characters and vehicles.                Soundtrack        7.5        The music on the radio stations, while not bad, leaves a lot to be desired. After the amazing soundtracks of Saints Row: The Third and Saints Row 2, I feel as if we should have expected more from this one. All-in-all though, still a pretty good, not so bad soundtrack.                Sound Effects        8.5        The sound effects throughout the game range from disappointing to absolutely perfect. A lot of the lower tier weapons (mostly the ones you are more likely to find in the real world) lack any kind of real umph, making them feel weaker than I feel they were intended to be. The more creative weapons, however, generally get me excited at the very thought of pulling them out. There is no joy like unleashing the power of the Dubstep Cannon.                Story        9.0        As Saints Row has shown with its previous installment, it pulls no punches as far as going as ridiculous as they can possibly go. As the newly elected President, it is your job to save the world from an oncoming alien invasion, getting abducted and sent into a Matrix-like simulation of the city from the third game. The main difference is that, since it is no longer grounded by the rules of reality, you can now develop superpowers as you progress through the game's story and side missions. While remaining silly and over the top throughout, Saints Row IV still manages to keep you attached to the characters, keeping small quirks and emotional moments right where they need to be. The only major complaint that I had with this story is when you do reach the end of the game, the ending boss fight leaves a lot to be desired, and the bad guy is not in the game nearly as much as he should be.                Overall        8.25        While I'll admit I was a little bit disappointed to see that this game took place in the same city as the last game, the new abilities really gave the game a face lift for me. It still packs the hilarious punch of the last game and provides you with something all together new to do. If you're looking for a game like Grand Theft Auto or the first three Saints Row games, honestly, I'd keep looking, but if you are a fan of the series and don't mind a more Prototype-like experience, I would highly recommend this one.\n\nYou can skip on most of the DLC though, it's mostly pretty disappointing.

reviewText: Saints Row IV is a riot. The superhero action exceeds that of games like Prototype, and it has many of the same feature experiences as Saints III. In some ways I enjoy 3 more just because the world is a little more simultation -- not so much Matrix. But Row 4 is a whole different kind of fun with super powers. There are also a host of mini-games, each fun in its own way. There's a million DLC for the whole paper dolls aspect of the game: Truly whatever avatar you wish to imagine yourself as is available. There is definitely an end to 3 when you've basically completed all the missions -- I don't know if the same thing happens in 4 or not. There's a lot of room to play in the first 50 hours. Enjoy!

reviewText: Saints Row IV is a hilariously fun open world game that will keep you coming back for more. While different from its predecessors, in that it goes “matrix” on you, it still has all the outlandish carnage and comedy of its forbearers all wrapped in a polished gameplay experience. For those achievement/item collecting ♥♥♥♥♥s out there, this game provides plenty of opportunities to fulfill such desires. Although some activities can feel repetitive, the sheer ridiculousness of most situations still makes it an enjoyable experience. The backstories of each character are hilarious and fun to discover. The occasional flash-backs to various iconic video game styles is also a nice touch. Achieving 100% control of Steelport and completing the campaign will leave you feeling accomplished but also a tad bit sad, driving you to start a brand new game as an entirely different character altogether. My only negative with the PC version is the extremely poor multiplayer matchmaking. If you do not have friends that play the game it is almost impossible to find somebody to play with through steam matchmaking. Despite this, one can find people to play with through the forums. Overall Saints Row IV is one of my favorite games of the past year.

reviewText: I found this game surprisingly entertaining. The storyline is competely over-the-top and makes so many references to popular culture that would be far too numerous for me to mention here. Imagine yourself being put as the main protagonist as you save the world from an alien invasion. But instead of a tired cliche, you get suprisingly well-defined controls for running, driving, fighting, shooting and exploring this world that doesn't take itself too seriously. Don't think of it as some GTA knock-off and just enjoy the ride while it lasts.

reviewText:
Now, Saints Row IV is fully off the walls crazy, but you know that from watching the trailer. What you don't know is all the crazy referential jokes included in that as well. Saints Row IV Is a complete and total ride, and it was so much fun from start to finish. Let me break this down for you:
Story: 9/10
As a sci fi nerd, I enjoyed the hell out of the story. Yes, it is a bit barebones, just you become president, aliens attack and abduct you and your crew, then blow up the earth, and you want revenge. Simple right? Well, sort of. The main villian Zinyak really makes you hate him by the final confrontation. He takes over the radio, changes things in the simulation, and belittles you to the very end. Just another one of those villians you love to hate. All the main characters in your crew are back from the last one and beyond, and all have much to say. There are these loyalty missions where you usually do unfinished buisness from their personal nightmare while giving them superpowers as well. Every single one was a lot of fun, and I don't regret any of them. Overall, the story is crazy and fun as well as quite good, but not perfect, but worth every second I put into it.

Graphics/Sound: Graphics 7/10 Sound 10/10
Normally I wouldn't split these, but it really needed to be done in this case. The graphics are alright. Beyond the amazing sci fi night scenery of Steelport, the graphics aren't too much to write home about. The sound however is what kills it. Although, to be more specific, the music. The radio is much better in this game. AI woul refuse to listen to anything but the 80s channel, and beat dudes up to saftey dance, and it was so good! Plus theres killing people in a mech suit to You've Got The Touch"
date:
and so much more. The music is great!

Overall: 9/10

reviewText:
Saints Row IV was like a Roller Coaster ride. Ups and Downs all around. Here is the plot

After years of fighting gangs, the Saints become celebrities. Next they become special ops soldiers and take down a Terrorist: Cyrus who was the old former leader of the STAG. The Saints take him down and also disarm the bomb that could have wiped out America itself. The Boss (You) becomes president after the operation. Out of the blue an alien race drops into earth and takes all the humans into capsules in their ship. They are placed in a simulation living there nightmare. Will the saints save the world?

Gameplay: 7/10

The Gameplay is pretty fun. The superpowers are a cool addon giving you some fun fights with your enemy aliens and also helps you travel a bit more faster than usual. There is superpower upgrades that will give you powers such as blasting fire or freezing your foes. The problem about this is well.. The vehicles and some weapons are useless. Pistols are useless after you gain some skill and firepower with your Powers and vehicles are pretty much just there. There is some fun vehicles and the planes are still useful but there is no good use to the vehicles when you have fast running and jumping. Its not all that fun to use cars when you could just fly. The boss battles are entertaining though. Specially the huge Can that you have to fight. There is a good difficulty in the game that doesn't put a lot of difficulty spikes when playing which is always annoying. There is nothing else to say about the gameplay rather that it is fun but it is not something you could play again and again. Maybe 2-4 times you could replay this game but the Story is short. You can take about 8 hours of gametime just finishing the campaign. Its decent.

Sound and Music:

Sounds: 7.5/10
Music: 7/10

The sounds in this game are very refined and not bad quality. It also has the amazing dubstep gun that will never get old because it is sooo much fun! The sounds overall is good but the gun sounds are very weak. Good voice acting too!

The music is decent. There is some radios that isn't really something you would listen too all day but there ok. The music soundtrack for the game is good. The Armagaddon reference and parody with the Aerosmiths: Don't wanna miss a thing and some other songs are also there which references other media (Even What is love is there)

Overall some good sound and music for the ears.

Story: 7.8/10

The story is OK. It is not some great revenge story or some a fun alien movie. The thing that makes it great is the characters and dialouge, They are funny! It also mocks Mass Effects with the relationship system and some love-love scenes. There is nothing else to say but the Villian is brilliant. The story is feels a little to short though

Overall: 7.5/10

+Fun Characters
+Fun Gameplay

- Too short
- Inefficient weapons as you progress
- Very Useless vehicles as you progress
- You being the President is not expanded. You only feel like a President for like 5 minutes

I hope to see SRV as a more character driven action game (less focusing on shooting). Should be fun.

reviewText: Field        Rating        Comments                Graphics        8.0        Graphically, this isn't all that much of a step up from the last entry. While they aren't bad by any stretch of the imagination, they leave a little bit to be desired considering it's the same engine, same city, and mostly the same characters and vehicles.                Soundtrack        7.5        The music on the radio stations, while not bad, leaves a lot to be desired. After the amazing soundtracks of Saints Row: The Third and Saints Row 2, I feel as if we should have expected more from this one. All-in-all though, still a pretty good, not so bad soundtrack.                Sound Effects        8.5        The sound effects throughout the game range from disappointing to absolutely perfect. A lot of the lower tier weapons (mostly the ones you are more likely to find in the real world) lack any kind of real umph, making them feel weaker than I feel they were intended to be. The more creative weapons, however, generally get me excited at the very thought of pulling them out. There is no joy like unleashing the power of the Dubstep Cannon.                Story        9.0        As Saints Row has shown with its previous installment, it pulls no punches as far as going as ridiculous as they can possibly go. As the newly elected President, it is your job to save the world from an oncoming alien invasion, getting abducted and sent into a Matrix-like simulation of the city from the third game. The main difference is that, since it is no longer grounded by the rules of reality, you can now develop superpowers as you progress through the game's story and side missions. While remaining silly and over the top throughout, Saints Row IV still manages to keep you attached to the characters, keeping small quirks and emotional moments right where they need to be. The only major complaint that I had with this story is when you do reach the end of the game, the ending boss fight leaves a lot to be desired, and the bad guy is not in the game nearly as much as he should be.                Overall        8.25        While I'll admit I was a little bit disappointed to see that this game took place in the same city as the last game, the new abilities really gave the game a face lift for me. It still packs the hilarious punch of the last game and provides you with something all together new to do. If you're looking for a game like Grand Theft Auto or the first three Saints Row games, honestly, I'd keep looking, but if you are a fan of the series and don't mind a more Prototype-like experience, I would highly recommend this one.\n\nYou can skip on most of the DLC though, it's mostly pretty disappointing.

reviewText:
Saints Row IV was like a Roller Coaster ride. Ups and Downs all around. Here is the plot

After years of fighting gangs, the Saints become celebrities. Next they become special ops soldiers and take down a Terrorist: Cyrus who was the old former leader of the STAG. The Saints take him down and also disarm the bomb that could have wiped out America itself. The Boss (You) becomes president after the operation. Out of the blue an alien race drops into earth and takes all the humans into capsules in their ship. They are placed in a simulation living there nightmare. Will the saints save the world?

Gameplay: 7/10

The Gameplay is pretty fun. The superpowers are a cool addon giving you some fun fights with your enemy aliens and also helps you travel a bit more faster than usual. There is superpower upgrades that will give you powers such as blasting fire or freezing your foes. The problem about this is well.. The vehicles and some weapons are useless. Pistols are useless after you gain some skill and firepower with your Powers and vehicles are pretty much just there. There is some fun vehicles and the planes are still useful but there is no good use to the vehicles when you have fast running and jumping. Its not all that fun to use cars when you could just fly. The boss battles are entertaining though. Specially the huge Can that you have to fight. There is a good difficulty in the game that doesn't put a lot of difficulty spikes when playing which is always annoying. There is nothing else to say about the gameplay rather that it is fun but it is not something you could play again and again. Maybe 2-4 times you could replay this game but the Story is short. You can take about 8 hours of gametime just finishing the campaign. Its decent.

Sound and Music:

Sounds: 7.5/10
Music: 7/10

The sounds in this game are very refined and not bad quality. It also has the amazing dubstep gun that will never get old because it is sooo much fun! The sounds overall is good but the gun sounds are very weak. Good voice acting too!

The music is decent. There is some radios that isn't really something you would listen too all day but there ok. The music soundtrack for the game is good. The Armagaddon reference and parody with the Aerosmiths: Don't wanna miss a thing and some other songs are also there which references other media (Even What is love is there)

Overall some good sound and music for the ears.

Story: 7.8/10

The story is OK. It is not some great revenge story or some a fun alien movie. The thing that makes it great is the characters and dialouge, They are funny! It also mocks Mass Effects with the relationship system and some love-love scenes. There is nothing else to say but the Villian is brilliant. The story is feels a little to short though

Overall: 7.5/10

+Fun Characters
+Fun Gameplay

- Too short
- Inefficient weapons as you progress
- Very Useless vehicles as you progress
- You being the President is not expanded. You only feel like a President for like 5 minutes

reviewText:
Now, Saints Row IV is fully off the walls crazy, but you know that from watching the trailer. What you don't know is all the crazy referential jokes included in that as well. Saints Row IV Is a complete and total ride, and it was so much fun from start to finish. Let me break this down for you:
Story: 9/10
As a sci fi nerd, I enjoyed the hell out of the story. Yes, it is a bit barebones, just you become president, aliens attack and abduct you and your crew, then blow up the earth, and you want revenge. Simple right? Well, sort of. The main villian Zinyak really makes you hate him by the final confrontation. He takes over the radio, changes things in the simulation, and belittles you to the very end. Just another one of those villians you love to hate. All the main characters in your crew are back from the last one and beyond, and all have much to say. There are these loyalty missions where you usually do unfinished buisness from their personal nightmare while giving them superpowers as well. Every single one was a lot of fun, and I don't regret any of them. Overall, the story is crazy and fun as well as quite good, but not perfect, but worth every second I put into it.

Graphics/Sound: Graphics 7/10 Sound 10/10
Normally I wouldn't split these, but it really needed to be done in this case. The graphics are alright. Beyond the amazing sci fi night scenery of Steelport, the graphics aren't too much to write home about. The sound however is what kills it. Although, to be more specific, the music. The radio is much better in this game. AI woul refuse to listen to anything but the 80s channel, and beat dudes up to saftey dance, and it was so good! Plus theres killing people in a mech suit to You've Got The Touch"
date:
and so much more. The music is great!

Overall: 9/10
"

reviewText:
Would recommend but only if it's on sale. Solid, funny writing (parody galore), over the top action as you would expect from a Saints Row game. If you like the humour from last game, you won't be dissapointed. The super power gameplay mechanic plays pretty well but this game feels like it should have been an expansion rather than a full release (hence only buy it when it's on sale). The mechanic is expanded from what they had with 'Trouble with Clones' DLC from Saints Row 3 so if you enjoyed that, you'll definitely like this.

Fairly short game. I fnished all main story, loyalty missions, side missions and all collectibles except for the data clusters (super power upgrade currency) in about 20 hours. Plenty of padding with the side missions which is basically a set of activities. If you are not really a completionist, you can probably blitz through the main story and loyalty missions (worth doing) pretty quickly.

Technical side, no problems or game breaking bug encountered during my playthrough. I think it only crashed once.

reviewText:
this is it.

this is the saints row game that gave saints row its own 'identity' in the game world. it suddenly became a lot less of a gta clone and more of its own thing and it's pretty great. it's a somewhat short game(takes maybe 11 hours tops w/o grabbing all collectibles) that relies majorly on comedy and executes it pretty well.

the premise of the game is that in the prologue, your player, the boss, and the boss' friends/homies/whatever take down a terrorist who was a bad guy in saints row 3 and stop a nuclear missile from hitting the white house, enabling you to become the president of the USA and your homies to work as all the other important things. suddenly, aliens invade earth, and you're stuck in what is basically the matrix, inside of a simulation of the city of steelport(the city you play in in saints row 3). basically for the rest of the game you have to find your homies and rescue them and then kill the alien overlord, while doing a bunch of stuff throughout the altered simulation that is basically just a bunch of killing aliens.

the comedy is executed really well, the music is spot-on and the graphics, despite being somewhat cheesy for 2013, are pretty gorgeous when compared with the graphics of the previous saints row games(most of what was altered was lighting and environments. honestly, they didn't change many models but it's definitely a good improvement.). you also get bada$$ superpowers in the simulation and a bunch of new customisation options(even though they took away a small amount of the ones featured in saints row 3 for whatever reason), along with cool new weapons, new minigames that are enormous improvements on some of the boring stuff to be found in saints row 3, and badass new vehicles(you can even steal the alien vehicles.).

also there are text adventures, you can change the day/night cycle after the end of the game, and the best part about it is the 80s sidescroller part(you'll see what i mean).

please buy it if you're not an overly offended person 9/10

reviewText:
Thoughts on this game are so mixed.

I'll start with the bad here. First, if you think SR3 was a pretty big step away from the concept of Saint's Row, this game just slaps the very franchise right in the face. It's no longer about gangs and owning the city and the beautiful things that made up Saint's Row 1 and 2. Extremely disappointing that they continued to back away from that concept. Second, the map is just a retextured steelport from SR3, pretty much detail for detail. I realized that 1 and 2 reused Stillwater, but 2 still expanded the map and improved it a bit. The same is not at all true for 4, which is also disappointing and a little boring. As I think others have said, the map could have just been a mod for 3. Third, the game starts by assuming which way you finished SR3, which is lame. As the game goes on, it just creates random needless holes regarding the same topic. Senseless and stupid.  Finally, I thought some missions, particularly a certain Keith David mission, get so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ out there that I feel like I need to be doing so some serious drugs to make sense of what's going on.

However, despite all these complaints, this is still honestly a great game. Just not a great Saint's Row game. Do yourself a favor and come into this expecting a whole new game, not SR. You'll get alot more fun out of it that way. The superpowers are a fun twist that I didn't expect myself to like. The soundtrack was very well chosen for this game, more so than 1-3 in my opinion. Loyalty missions are fun and creative. All charcters, new and old, are fun to call in and hard to pick favorites. The massive amount of references, mostly sci-fi stuff, is great to hear and fun to catch. More than anything, I think this game really makes you feel pretty badass, and that's always awesome, or at least for me.

Really, this game comes up to be a bad good game that is useful for senseless fun and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, which isn't always a bad thing. If you can get over that this isn't Saint's Row aside from the charcters, this is probably worth your time.

Much Like Saints Row: The Third. This game is Amazing, I cannot express how much I love this game. BUY IT NOW!

Without being biased it is an overall fantastic game. It combines addicting third person action gameplayWITH SUPERPOWERS and fantastic voice acting to make it a perfect comedy. DLC - I recommend buying How The Saints Saved Christmas and Enter the Dominatrix‎, these both add a great new storyline that will take about 1 hour each to complete
The others however only add cosmetics/new weapons and cheats that don't really add much to the game.

reviewText:
Being the fourth in the series, Saints Row 4 has a rich backstory and large cast of characters that are constantly referenced throughout the game. I only played parts 3 and 4, so I recognized about 3/4 of the characters in the game.  For those unfamiliar, the Saints Row franchise seems to be a parody of the Grand Theft Auto franchise, but I can’t say for sure, since I haven’t played any of the GTA games.

Short recap of Saints Row the Third (the previous game):
The Third Street Saints (a street gang) have become world famous pop culture icons despite being a bunch of criminals. They have their own TV shows, sports drink, and people want to grow up to be like them. Unfortunately, a large and powerful crime Syndicate has come to town to destroy the Saints and take over the city. And that’s not all. The US Military (or some kind of military unit) has been dispatched to deal with the Saints as well, with access to some very high tech equipment.

In Saints Row 4, after saving the world from the villains in SR3, the Boss of the Saints (you) has been elected President of the United States. Things are going great up until an alien invasion devastates the planet and kidnaps a bunch of humans to be locked in a computer simulation (basically the Matrix). You discover that by causing mayhem and absorbing “code” in the simulation, you can acquire super powers such as super running speed, super jumping , and later on, energy blasts/telekinesis/super stomps. These abilities, mixed with an arsenal of weapons (human and alien) can be used to trash the game world and try to bring the whole system down. Most of Saints Row 4 takes place in the computer simulation, but there are segments where you’re in the “real world” as well. In the real world you can interact with rescued team members (with a romance system) and pilot an alien space ship around.

Like its predecessors, Saints Row 4 is a third person shooter with a large city you can walk, drive, or fly through. Weapons are bought and upgraded in gun shops found all over the city along with clothing stores (for character customization) and car shops. The city is filled with various activities and missions that you can start by just walking up and pressing a key. These include Mayhem (Blow up as much as you can with the weapons given to you in a time limit), Racing, and Insurance Fraud (you ragdoll around being hit by cars to rack up a huge medical bill). With the addition of super powers, there’s a lot more variety than in the previous games, but it really makes cars and even planes obsolete since you can run/super jump faster than any vehicle.

There are also a large number of collectibles in the game such as data clusters (used to upgrade your powers) and Audio Logs, which are short recorded messages giving you backstory. I thought it would be impossible to collect them all for the Steam achievement but on my second playthrough it looks like I might actually do it. This is because your game map is much more detailed than I realized, and after a particular upgrade, you will be able to see all the collectibles on your map (kind of like the Batman Arkham games but without puzzles blocking you). By the way I should probably note that the achievements in SR4 are for a single playthrough. You can’t play through the game 10 times and think everything will add up to the achievement goal. For example you actually have to kill 1000 aliens with your superpowers in one playthrough. This means grinding is necessary on a few of the achievements.

Pros:
+A lot of humor in the game with its over the top story and characters. The game is definitely a parody with silly names and crazy missions.
+A lot of variety in gameplay. There’s everything from side scrolling 2-D fighting, to tank/mech battles, to fighting Godzilla size monsters. Remember that the game world is a computer simulation so they can do just about anything they want.
+The story is decent and the game is pretty long so you should get your money’s worth. It also has a co-op mode which I haven’t tried. It seems to be its own save file though, independent of your single player campaign.

Cons:
-You’ll notice that there is a lot of repetition in the game despite the variety of activities you can take part in. Most of the side quests are the same (Do a series of mini-games). You can bypass them of course, but you’d miss out on unlocking upgrades to your superpowers.
-Some of the Steam achievements seem like they would take forever to complete such as “complete ALL challenges” (challenges are like in game achievements). No doubt I could do them eventually, but it would take an extra 50 hours of gameplay. And remember it needs to be in a single playthrough. Also, a bunch of achievements are for the game’s DLCs which I don’t own.

Overall, the game is worth playing if you can get your hands on it. Steam had a free weekend a while back and I know a couple people who finished the game during the 3 days. The price hasn’t quite dropped to “bargain bin” level though it’s on sale occasionally. I’ve heard some people say the game is like a DLC for Saints Row the Third, and I can see what they mean. The graphics are nearly identical (as far as I can remember) and both have the same gameplay feel (except with super powers). If you liked Grand Theft Auto / Sleeping Dogs type games but wished you weren’t restrained by the limitations of reality, give Saints Row 4 a try.

reviewText:
I can't think of a better game I've played this year, sometimes the game seems nonsensical but it laughs at itself for it, throughout the entire thing this game is for fun, everything about it is just fun.

It steals ideas from other games and films but who cares? The story is excellent, over the top and hilarious fun to play with a friend, if you can port your character from SR3 too using the website then you can continue the story of your character.

Negatives :
+ Shame they lost the hispanic voice, but the french one is decent enough.
+ Multiplayer occasionally broke, reconnecting normally fixed it, just one nearly game breaking issue near the end where one of us had to wait at the start of the map for the other to finish a section.

I can't remember if I've played a better game this year, but I do know this is the most fun I've had on a game for ages.

reviewText:
I really love SR 2 and 3. I love the gang I'm running, love the gang members Pierce, Johnny, Shaundi and so on. You know, it's hard to be a better game than GTA series if you wanna just create a crime sandbox game. But I think SR just found another effective way to go rather than dumb imitation. It's not just doing jobs for others, from now on you work for your own crew. You are the boss( but in fact i don't feel like a boss to do lota errands myself==). And there's some more unique thing, that is being ridiculous and absurd since SR 3. I love all those. But, I just reckon SR 4 is a little boring to play. The whole game just feels like a group of small games. However you can relax yourself to play like a superman.  What i mean is i love 2&3 much more than this one, but after all it's a good game to play.
In all:
+Nice super power design.
+Fantastic music.
+Wonderful crew, my dream team!
+Funny dialogues and world.
+Unique and intersting small games.
-Weak story, maybe just for fun.
-Just feel like a small game bundle... not like it used to be.
-Vehicles are unnecessary indeed.
7.5/10

reviewText:
Saints Row IV or better known as, enter the dominatirx, Is fun,funny,super heroic,and chessy. If you were a fan of saints row the thrid,and liked its humor entrance into the franchise, then you know what you are about to walk into. But if you like the old classic saints row, then back away now, since this game changes everything.

Starting out with modern day saints row, you soon enter a simulation of your nightmare. You then are focused on getting out of there and saving your saints crew, and destoring zinyak and the aliens. Vehicles like cars, or tanks are not the best thing ever in this game since you are running at the speed of light, takes away that fact of using vehicles.

The weapons of saints row 4 are fun and funny to mess with, although the dubstep gun maybe a little to over hyped. But with the customization this game has for its weapons, you will not be disappointed what so ever. From skins and upgrades, to wacky dlc's that add extra crazy stuff to the game. The character creation and buying clothing is much like saints row the thrid but there is a twist now you must hack the stores, since they were shutdown by zinyak.

All and all this game is a great game to mess around with. I played with a couple of friends and it was a blast for co-op fun, the story although is not serously but still enjoyable. If you have not yet to pick up this game, i recommened this game,since it was one of 2013's hits!

reviewText: Great Game
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've heard SR described as “GTA that doesn't take itself seriously”. I haven't played the previous installments, but if the 4th is any indication, the description is pretty accurate: it's an open world game where you run, drive and fly to participate in various activities that more often than not end up with you being chased by the police – or the setting's local equivalent of it.

In SR4 we assume the role of the president of the United States, who is a superhero at the same time. The game shows exactly how serious it's going to be with an opening sequence where the player character kills a bunch of terrorists, jumps on top of a nuclear warhead, detonates it mid-flight to end up jumping down to the ground and landing right on the presidental chair in the Oval Office. Soon after that the alien invasion begins, and we end up trapped in a computer simulation with all the other humans while our real bodies are locked in red containers full of life supporting fluids. We're soon taught how to bend the rules of the simulation which effectively gives us superpowers, allowing us to fight the oppressors. Sounds familiar?

While the Matrix is easily the most prevalent inspiration for the game, it draws ideas from tons of other works of popular culture, to the point where I'm not sure whether it's meant as a parody or a tribute. One mission will have you crawl through a level disguised as a cardboard box (with the appropiate Metal Gear Solid sound effects), in the other you are put in a 2d side-scrolling beat-em-up, with mechanics about as sophisticated as Franko had (anyone still remember it?). About every other story quest mocks or refers to something, but I haven't found it annoying or obnoxious at any point. The main storyline is quite fun, funny and enjoyable; the only thing that I can pick on in this game is... everything else.

It seems to me that Saints Row IV would be a much better game if it was a bit smaller and more focused. It gives you a massive amount of options to upgrade and customize your cars, which seems like a good thing, except that with your superpowers you run much faster than any vehicle drives, making them pretty much useless. You get a pretty impressive arsenal of weapons, ranging from typical pistols, shotguns and rifles to goofy, (and actually quite hilarious) stuff like a rectal probe, dubstep gun, a black hole generator or a strangely familiar Laser Sword. Almost all of them can be upgraded in weapon stores, but the game is easy enough to beat it entirely with a ♥♥♥♥♥ bat (I didn't actually try, but I did beat a few combat-focused side missions equipped with nothing else but the aforementioned sex toy). The game features a Homies system, where you can either recruit your gangmembers from the street or call them from your phone to join you in battle, but it never seemed necessary, with the superpowers giving you so powerful AoE attacks that 3 NPC shooting their guns look mildly amusing at best. The game gives you a lot of mechanics to use and play with, but it doesn't really capitalize on any of them. It even allows customizable skins on your weapons (presumably to have a potential to crank up some DLC money), which I enabled at the beginning of the game but never even noticed them in my 21 hours of playing it.

The game has a lot of features that see little to no use in it, yet it fills your time with dozens of similar, repetitive minigames, ranging from quite enjoyable (like hacking stores in form of a classic “plumber” game) to straight up annoying (like ragdolling through the streets trying to hurt yourself as much as possible, that being a lot less fun than it possibly sounds like). It seems like for the amount of content and mechanics that the game has, the side missions could be a bit more elaborate and original, rather than being a combination of 10 or so minigames over and over again – to the point where the reasoning of your questgivers literally becomes “I don't want to waste my breath, just go blow ♥♥♥♥ up, okay?” at some point.

Apart from missions we get the expected open world goodies like collectibles scattered all across the city, a chance to (re)play the minigames that the side quests require you to do, extremely high structures to climb, and of course countless excuses for mayhem and havoc that we all know and love. All that acompanied by 8-ish radio stations, which we can thankfully listen to also when on foot, which is quite useful in a game where cars are mostly decorative. I found the music quite okay, ranging from rock, reggae to some heavier techno. There was nothing like the absurd talk show station you may have liked in GTA, the only ersatz being a clearly stoned announcer in the dubstep-y station. Still, nothing to complain about.

All in all, I quite enjoyed my time with Saints Row IV. While I do think that the huge part of the game is mediocre at best and it'll be better off without it, the main story is pretty solid and quite fun. Being the completionist that I am I couldn't ignore all the sidequests, even after I decided that they're bad and I don't like them, but I can easily recommend picking the game up just to play the story quests. It's nothing special, ambitious or worth replaying, but it does have its memorable moments that still make me giggle inside when I think about them. I'd advise to not bother with sidequests to much, since the rewards for them are negligible at best and their gameplay isn't very fun itself, but the main storyline should give you about 8 hours of fun. A pretty fun game for those evenings when you don't feel like doing anything constructive and want to lay back and relax with something that'll make you smile and rapidly exhale through your nose every now and again.
