reviewText:
The first Saints Row game was nothing more than a cheap knock off, I liked the 80's metal soundtrack in the game but that was all it had going for it. The second game is when things got entertaining, they just started to parodize the whole gang thing a lot more and poke fun at some relevant societal topics. But the third game is when Volition really started to have fun poking fun at how weird the real world was. Saints Row: The Third wasn't only fun to play but the way it poked fun at the reality tv craze, and Stag was obviously a jab at how Bush handled the war on terror, and it was all done in a very National Lampoon way which was amusing. Well Saints Row IV, it merely picks up where they left off in three and takes even mroe jabs at a lot of the absurd things in the US, and it pays homage to so many things from the 80's you'll lose count. There's the level that totally pays homage to They Live and a Christmas Story (briefly), and then there's tons of weapons from 80's classics like Robocop, Aliens, and GI Joe. And the christmas expansion, the first level is basically a re-creation of the old studio lot where they shot Jaws, Gremlins, and numerous other classics. But towards the end when it pays homage to the animated Transformers film, and even uses the Stan Bush song from the film, that was just a golden moment in the game.

But I'm praising the satire and how they paid homage to so many great films and cartoons and not talking about the gameplay. Gameplay wise the game is pretty fun and the super powers the player can use in the viritual world add a whole new level of gameplay to the franchise since in earlier games, the player had to rely on vehicles to get anywhere fast and always rely on guns or grenades, but in the 4th game the player could still go the gun and grenade route or freeze people or turn them into gold or use telekenisis and throw them into the sky. In short, the game allows players to just go crazy when it comes to taking out pedestrians and the aliens. The controls are as smooth as the third game, which I'm thankful for since Saints Row 2 for the PC, the driving controls were just horrible. If one enjoys open world games where they can just go crazy, this game should please them. But I highly recommend getting the Game of the Century version, or at the very least the base game and the christmas expansion pack. While I adore Volition's sense of humor when it comes ot the SR franchise, Enter the Dominatrix gets a little too corny, while the Christmas expansion is hands down a far better expansion pack. I don't recommend playing any of the expansions until after finishing the main game though since the expansions will spoil a few things otherwise.

However, while I think the game is highly entertaining and totally worth dropping 10-20 on, it does have its flaws and they're the same exact flaws the third game had.

1. The game doesn't have the cool drug and booze thing from the second game, I found it highly amusing how the character could get drunk or stoned in the second game and was sad to see them ditch the ability to do that in the third and fourth. To be fair, it could have been because some countries ban games with drug content, like Australia.

2. The really cool interior locations like the mall in Saints Row 2 added a lot of fun to the game, it was a blast to ♥♥♥♥ off the security guards and then just cause tons of trouble. But Saints Row 3 and 4 just don't have any of those types of interior locations, which is a shame.

3. The player can still play in the water in three and four but it doesn't take long to notice the water isn't used by any of the npc's like in the 2nd game. There aren't any npc's jet ski'ing or driving boats or anything like that, the water is just lifeless.

If Saints Row 5 brings back just 1 or 2 of those three things, I'll love it to pieces.

reviewText:
INCLUSION DONE RIGHT
As a gay man I struggle to find games that will let me have an experience I identify with. It isn't that easy to find games where women aren't obejcts, where men don't have to be beefy to be called man and where being gay is not a reason for jokes. SR4, as nonsense, bizarre, ludicrous and offensive as it is, avoids stereotypes and community/group/race/gender specific jokes better than many before and after it!

The title follows the leader of the Third Street Saints as he/she becomes president of the United States. Within the first minutes of gameplay an alien invasion takes place and thus starts the greatest masterpiece in sandbox history. In the simulation where the alien overlord emprisoned you and your friends, you have access to super powers, vehicles -- which you can spawn from almost anywhere --, ships, a large variety of the coolest weapons ever and the possibility to be whoever you want. No, literally. You want to be a beefy guy? Go for it! Want to be a sexy babe? You can do that! Or perhaps you'd like to be a transgender sparkly green alien filled with tattoos? Yes, perfectly possible! In addition to that, the developers did the sexy-powerful female role right with characters like Shaundi, Asha and [surprisingly] Kinzie, who are complex enough to be labeled anything but that girl with the big ♥♥♥♥". And although there are jokes regarding homosexuality

reviewText:
Saints Row IV is the sequel to Saints Row: The Third, an open-world game that split many audiences. On one hand, many newcomers to the series and some older fans enjoyed the over-the-top style that that game possessed. On the other hand, many longtime fans were left disappointed. The story had little consistency, Steelport was smaller than the more diverse Stilwater, and the humour, while hilarious at first, wore itself thin and became very predictable. While I enjoyed both Saints Row 2 and it's successor, I did understand while many fans were so disappointed with SR:TT and were hesistant about the fourth entry, which was originally intended as a DLC. Well, Saints Row IV arrived months ago, and with the current sale going on (or future sales), some of you may wonder whether this game is worth the asking price, and the answer depends on your taste.
The game, like it's predecessor, focuses on over-the-top action and hilarious weapons. I'll start with the story, which is ...interesting. . Without going into too much detail, your character becomes the President, fights aliens, and gets dropped into a Matrix-like simulation. The first few hours are a good indication for the rest of the game. The writing is much better, and actually made me laugh out loud on multiple occasions (not that Saints Row the Third didn't). However, a lot of it relies on references to games/movies like Metal Gear Solid, the Matrix, and Zero Dark Thirty. While these do offer some good chuckles. they also underline a big problem with the game: it's unoriginal. Rather than actually provide commentary or put interesting twists on these references, it merely admits the existence of them.
This unoriginality carries over to the gameplay, too. The game gives you superhuman abilities that are eerily similar to those that are featured in Crackdown and Prototype. While these powers are undeniably fun, the fact that they're carried over from other franchises means that these powers don't mesh well with existing mechanics. Saints Row started out with a large focus on jacking vechicles, but I didn't do that more than a handful of times in this game. Why enter a car when you can run faster than it from the beginning? Still, it's hard to deny the joy that these powers bring to the game. You're also given other powers, such as buffs, telekenesis, etc., and they compliment the gunplay very well, which is good, because the gunplay is underdeveloped. There's no cover system, so you'll have to just awkwardly crouch behind crates and buldings. While this was disappointing, I was able to look past this because the combat was so much fun. The weapons, like the Dubstep gun and the Abduction gun (both are very self-explanatory), make otherwise-stale gameplay fresh, although they do feel a bit out of place when offset by the gray and bleak Steelport. Yeah, Steelport is back, and somehow it's become more lifeless. The game is set in perpetual darkness, and you can't change the time of day until you finish the game. While the ability to change the tone of the game is very cool, I felt that the game would have been much more enjoyable if we were given these abilities upfront, and could unlock the effects as we progressed through the game. Overall, there's not much more to say about the gameplay, other than it's fun. Messy fun, but fun none-the-less.
The game boasts higher production values than any of the others in the series. This is apparent by the soundtrack, which features a good mix of memorable hits, modern tracks, and a few guilty pleasures. The visuals, however, feel outdated, and the game looks somewhat bleak with the black color pallet. The game runs very well, only crashing once, so I could look past the visual limits of the game.
All in all, Saints Row IV succeeds despite it's flaws. It's unoriginal, it's messy, and it shouldn't work. But it does. The game is undeniably fun, and if you're OK with a shallow yet entertaining game, this is definately a wise investment.

reviewText: Oh boy... what can I say? Just finished the game and now I don't know what I'm gonna do with my life! LOL Well, I'm completely in love about Saints Row franchise. I started with the third one, and of course the fourh became the priority of my wishlist right after. Saints Row IV has basically the same gameplay of its predecessor, but with some new, fun and useful elements: superpowers. This kinda eliminates the need of using cars or aircrafts, but you still can use them anyway. The storyline evolves surprises and elements that has flashbacks about the 3 other Saints Row games, with jokes and past stories about the characters that will make you want to play the other games if you didn't. The Genki Bowl activities are specially funnier (they used to annoy me a little on the third one). Again, the game is full of surprises and scenes that make you laugh many times. For me, this franchise is the best one I'll ever play in my life, because I never had so much fun in a game like I had with this one. I love the songs, the characters, the story, everything.\n\nOBS: I REALLY recommend playing at least Saints Row: The Third before playing this one because of the storyline, gameplay and also for the better understanding of some jokes.

reviewText:
WARNING: For full disclosure of why the game dissapointed, there is SPOILERS of what does and worse, what does NOT occur.

[Spoilers]
After it became available for the free weekend I decided to give Deep Silver a chance to try to dazzle me. And at first, dazzle me it did indeed. It seemed like there was underlying plot by Zinyak to 'break' the main character's will, since he himself says he can't wait to do it. Putting you in a simulation where the Earth is destroyed seemed to me a good way to do that. Then when you get power armor that just happens to have the exact same powers you hacked into the simulation earlier... I thought it was screaming twist ending. I thought the whole plot was Zinyak trying to break the President of the United State's Will so that he could easily conquer the planet, pretending it to be softpower tactics and earning some points with his government.

Instead, the ending is he just says screw it I'll kill you. Then you pull out his head, rule over the Zin, and dance. 0/10 Storytelling, at best misleading, at worst monstrously rediculous. Don't get me wrong, it's funny, just not a good story.
[/spoilers]

Okay, so the story didn't dazzle, in all hindsight it seems it just wasn't what they were trying to go for.
How was the gameplay? Except for Shaundi's storyline mission, pretty decent. Matt Miller, while loathed, made me truly believe this was a game in love with other games. This game does vary from others I have played, with enough constant variety to keep you interested until the very end.
7/10, While none of the gameplay is at all original (granted, hard to do these days), they manage well enough to acually truly entertain you for one linear playthrough. And throughout the story, it has some of the better superhero gameplay I've played in a while. However, if you try to steer off the story, you'll find that while there is some variety of minigames, they are merely lesser versions of alternative games and highly repetetive and quickly menotenous.


tldr; All in all it's not necessarily a bad game. The problem is that the best gameplay is following the storyline, otherwise the copy-paste repetitiveness of the character missions are likely to bore you, and for me the storyline was poorly written. This seems to be a game to buy, and only play through the story for the lols, and then dump it.

Super tldr; If you consider the current pricetag worth 12 hours (your story miles may vary) of linear but mostly entertaining gameplay and comedy, go ahead. Otherwise steer clear.

reviewText:
The Saints are back! Well, sort of. Fans of the first 3 Saints games may be in for a bit of a surprise, that is either going to impress them, or send them into a fit of rage. While other Saints games have been no stranger to going way out into left field, the 4th entry into this series seems to push the envelope even further. So far in fact that it seems like a completely new genre entry into the series. I'm sure by now you know the gist of the game. The gist is that you are no longer tied the laws of normal physics. Why? You progressively and eventually achieve becoming a mother #$%@ing superhero! Oh, and did I mention you are also the President of the United States? Yeah, from just a gangbanger, to a man in tights! Or whwtaever you want to wear to be honest.


Saints Row completely flips the script of previous Saints games, and has you now instead of fighting rival gangs, taking on a legion of aliens bent on destroying everything you care about. You'll meet familiar faces from the past, and run and gun or jump (over buildings mind you) and pound the ground with a bevy of your closest friends from the Saints universe. And Keith David too!

Yeah, you can run at lightning speeds, jump long distances, use telekinetic powers, and a lot more. The melee fighting is a lot better, but still a little lacking. However, punches go hard this time, so it's a lot more satisfying. Like punching a car, and seeing it knocked back quite a distance. You still get guns and other weapons (and LOTS of skins for them). And the way the game flows in combat, you'll find yourself mixing it up with all assortments of moves. Mainly due to limited ammo, and a meter for combat superpowers. This way you're not just spamming one thing over and over again. This makes for some fast and furious action, and I love it!

As far as traveling goes, you do get vehicles. But with how fast you can move in the game, they almost feel like an afterthought. That is of course for aerial vehicles, which can still be useful. This being because while you can jump super high, or launch yourself very far, and even glide long distances, you still never get the ability to fly.

As for the lack of interest in using vehicles which most people find not necessary, the game features the ability to listen to your favorite radio stations usually found in the vehicles, now outside of the vehicles at any time. And this my friends, is quite the dream. The soundtrack has some choice tunes, featuring a wide assortment of genres, and throwback classics. I was floored when I ran into a pack of alien enemies, and The Touch" by Stan Bush started playing. It made me feel...well...It made me feel like a bad ♥♥♥! The cheesy 80's centric music blaring while I'm zooming in and out of these enemies
recommended: and feeling like a god. I loved every minute of that. And it was purely by chance. Just some good timing is all.\n\nBut not to worry
hoursPlayed: Saints IV makes good use of scripted badassery

reviewText:
Painfully short. The game was entertaining, but even after purchasing the Enter the Dominatrix DLC I have amassed only 27hrs of game time.
You can't attribute it entirely to the super powers and ease of travel. I think there was just less to do, less story, fewer missions, less incentive to get certain achievements.

I don't think SR IV is the game it could have been. For a sandbox action game, 27 hours doesn't cut it. 45 minutes of addditional game play in the form of DLC doesn't cut it.

I wanted more out of this, Volition. SR3 is one of my favourite games, SR IV is a poor successor.

TL;DR: if you're OK with blowing things up with fun powers for under 30hrs, then this is what you want. If you were expecting a grand step forward from SR3 and a sequel that would sratch the itch that game left on your soul? Give this a pass. Play GTA IV instead.

reviewText: Incredibly silly but also incredibly fun. Saints Row IV is a juvenile power fantasy in videogame form, in the best way possible - it knows its being silly, and delights in it, from the Streets of Rage sidescroller, through Tim Curry esque bad guy, and the random visits to other games and genres along the way, it's all about having fun.\n\nIf you didn't care for the previous games (which honestly started out as bad GTA clones, but slowly got better), but like messing around in other sandbox games with cheats enabled, this may be the game for you.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Gameplay: The addition of super powers to Saints Row IV makes the gameplay much more fun throughout the approximately 10 hour campaign. Super jump, super sprint and a host of other abilities turn ordinary enemy encounters and travelling into much more enjoyable experiences than they otherwise normally would be. As well as this the general gunplay is quite satisfying, but unfortunately the driving is the weakest aspect (although this becomes irrelevant very early into the game, as your super powers make using traditional vehicles uneccessary, save for certain scripted sections).

Story: The game is consistently well written, with witty dialogue from most minor and major characters, an interesting narrative and many humorous moments.

Graphics: The city is very much a replica of Steelport from Saints Row: The Third, but some unique visual effects make it seem unique. This visual design also extends to the characters and weapons, which are pseudo-realistic in design, with lots of detail and character.

Sound: The game's soundtrack is very good, with lots of exciting songs that make the gameplay more thrilling and enjoyable. The voice acting is also very good, with characters portraying many subtleties through their intonations and general dialogues.

Re-playability: There are literally over a thousand various collectables scattered throughout the world, an abundance of activities to complete, many character progressions to earn and buy, and much more. In total there is about 35 hours of gameplay, for the completionist.

reviewText: Seaking for a game like GTA or Sleeping Dogs? This franchise is for you! I played the second, finished the third and the fourth and I will probably keep on playing. They'll come join the party!\n\nMy way to describe Saints Row to people who never heard of it: It's GTA on acid.

reviewText: The game itself is great, but what I found frustrating were the powers. At face value they seem cool, but over time I started feeling like the game experience was shallow because of them. Giant, unlimited explosions that killed everything around me made every gun in the game useless. Super-dashing took away any need to steal a car and make it my own with a custom paint job and meticulous body upgrades. Super-jumping took away the amazing feeling of stealing a plane or helicopter and parachuting out of an emergency landing. For every instant-gratification super power that emerged, it took away from a previous good feeling I had playing Saints Row 3.\n\nIt's a good game so I have to recommend it, but I feel a little sad because instead of getting more" of what I used to love
date: I got a different dish than what I was expecting."

reviewText:
It amazes me how a game that's 80% mini-games can have such a cohesive storyline and emersive and fun game play.  It's like a masterful puzzle full of tiny enjoyable puzzles.  I would recommend this game to anyone who's a fan of shooters, puzzle games, and good, dirty, over-the-top fun.  I could not stop playing and I mean that in a literal sense.  I ate through the entire story-line in three days.

I will also say this is a skillful use of past content with a nice inject of fresh content.  A few cosmetic changes here and there and it's pretty much the same map as SR:III.  They way it's done feels right with the storyline and gives a odd sense of nostalgia.  Most of the mini-games are new due to the fact they include the use of super powers which are a blast to use.  Then there are the backstories and trips down memory lane artful packaged to give the player a serious case of the feels, a good laugh, and a metric ton of ♥♥♥-kicking fun.

You should have this game in your library.  Even if you don't like shooters.  Even if you don't see the point of the Dubstep gun.  Whatever your reservations may be, you need to put them aside and get this game.  It's so, so worth it.

reviewText:
If you are a fan of the over the top fun that is Saints Row 3, you will enjoy 4, hands down. However, if you are of the school thinking this is some sort of serious open world crime game -cough gta cough- You will be dissapointed and wondering what the hell you just signed on for.   I myself, love the zany so I absolutely love what I have played so far.
the Pros:  it's fun, explodey, crude and general mayhem at it's best. There are alot of activities to do and plenty of them to keep you distracted for hours.

the cons: This port from console is a bit easy if you ask me. Certain mechanics, when transferred to mouse become second nature, vs fighting with a controller as the challenge. (the sprint challenges for example, with a controller would pose a bit more challenge than someone who has much more control via a mouse) my partner and I got gold on the hard ones on the first run through on most of them, if not the first, then the second.

There are a few...bugs? that I noticed that make the game a bit um...broken in the player's favor, but it's questionable if it was on purpose or not. As we are basically in a broken version of the matrix.  I discovered, to my absolute mirth, that during a fraud mission, I could send my character careening and cartwheeling clear across town, racking up hundreds of thousands of dollars in one fall. My mate topped my 350k by hitting 510k ..the bum!  But when the challenge hits gold at 1.6m, and you can easily accomplish this, it makes you wonder where the challenge is.

Now...mind you , storyline wise we have not progressed very far, as the darn cookie crumb activities keep distracting us! oh look a mayhem!!   So I am hoping it will get a bit tougher.

Overall, this game is a fantastic I've had a crappy day and need to unwind with random chaos and take my frustrations out in explosive form on pixels." type of game. It's what I've always considered the franchise. Fun
recommended: and over the top.  If you lack a sense of humor for the rediculous

reviewText:
Once again we go to saints land and this time the trip was ....... WFTW!
That means what the f--- wow.
Not a bad wtfw.  Sort of a mixed bag really.
If you liked saints row the third you will love this outting I know I did, but still I felt something was off to me.  I'd give this game an 85% out of 100%.  Its definitely enjoyable. here's my break down


The Awesome:

Hilarious storyline ... seriously if you want a serious story line you need look elsewhere.
Hilarious barriage of weapons , there's more guns and weapons than you'll ever find need of. Every one is a blast to use.
Great open world sandbox  play.

This Sucks:
Still no user radio.
Open world sandbox ... that is pretty much the same world you played in in SR3.
Like SR 3 did it lacks some of the activities its predecessors had.

That said again I'd call it an 85% if you enjoyed the rest of the series you'll love this game. If this is your first outing in saints world well ... you'll just scratch your head at the rediculous story and be generally clueless on who is who and what is what.

reviewText:
Saints Row IV adds a lot of chaos and confusion to the series, including a song of the same title. I was introduced to the series via Saints Row: The Third which I thought already pretty far fetched yet plausible to some degree, somehow this game does that while never ceasing to amaze me how far these boundaries get pushed. Story's pretty amazing yet it makes a lot of sense somehow. Lots of old characters get brought in without breaking paradoxes, brings a lot of character background with them through audio logs. Some text based RPG style adventures left around the simulation that tells Zinyak's history with sassy remarks which are pretty cool.

Gameplay starts off very similarly to it's predecessors, then comes in the super powers through an alien simulation and everything is amazing once we're past that. Mobility in the game is great because even though you can run/jump at superhuman speeds, using a vehicle is much more convenient and possibly faster sometimes. Also loves how the game integrates optional activities into side quests which tie in to territory control so you do not have to entirely go out of your way to do any of these activities to gain control. Activities such as insurance fraud from the older games are more plausible thanks to the simulation.

Was kind of disappointed by the lack of cutscenes that occur within the simulation because that's where you see your character all dolled up with your crew instead of the generic space uniforms. Loyalty missions also did not have any cutscenes whatsoever, which would have made the game more interesting and laid out. Overall pretty good game though, seeing as this is my longest review as of now. In short, if you loved SR:TT, why would you not buy this game? (other than the high retail price)

reviewText:
First off, the game is not terrible.

That being said, having been a huge fan of Saints Row: The Third, my expectations where sky high going into Saints Row IV.

The story of the game is even more over the top than previous Saints Row titles, though, the same can be said for a lot of the other aspects of the game. To sum it up, the story was entertaining enough, however, I don't think anyone ever played a Saints Row game for the story, so I concider this more a positive bi-factor.

The gameplay, now the gameplay in SR4 adds a lot variety, the introduction of super powers allows for even more rampage and destruction than ever before. With Blast powers, Telekinesis, Super jump and sprint, your character becomes a big ball of destruction goodness.

However, while super powers is a lot of fun to play around with, I feel it also takes a lot away from the game. The game is INCREDIBLY easy, even on the hardest difficulty. Activities from previous SR games, like Insurance Fraud" devolves into super jumping

reviewText: Saints Row IV is a video game that tries to be everything... and actually does a great job at it. The story continues from SR3, where the Leader of the Third Street Saints has gained enough popularity to become President. While the aspect of being US President is quicky diminished by an alien attack, it doesn't hurt the ridicolously over-the-top, hilarious and fun narrative. The most drastic change for franchise long-timers is that your avatar now has superpowers. This is easily the best thing about the game, despite that it destorys the point of driving cars in a franchise that was previously known as a GTA clone. The open-world is arguably less interesting than what it was in SR3, but the side content is addicting, fun, sometimes crazy, and worth it. Add in a co-op campaign option, and mind=blown. This game is fun in it's rawest state. 9/10\n\n(The Game has a free weekend, I totally recommend trying it out! Message me if you wanna play some co-op)

reviewText:
Once again, the Saints are back with some wacky adventures. Trapped inside a computer simulation, the game gives you free rein to kick some ♥♥♥ and get revenge for humanity.

Overall, Saints Row 4 is a VERY fun game. Saints Row is clearly now breaking away from another sandbox GTA style game to games where you can do random ♥♥♥♥ and have a lot of fun. This works for them very well and surprisingly, they deliver an exciting superhero game with a compelling, if at times ridiculous, story.

Fans of the Saints Row series will really enjoy the callbacks 4 makes to previous games (especially 2 and 3) but new players may be a little confused. I'd definitely recommend skimming the plots of previous games before playing 4.

I would probably still recommend 3 over 4 but this is still a great game with lots of fun to be had.

reviewText:
The biggest shame about Saints Row IV is that most people will ignore it as a bad GTA clone. In reality, though, this game is perhaps the most amazing super-villain simulator ever.

From the amazingly over-the-top story to the incredible selection of songs, which reminds me of what I loved about the last GTA I really loved, Vice City, it gets so much right that even where it goes wrong I'm willing to forgive it.

The only sandbox I've had as much fun in recently was Just Cause 2 which says a lot.

Get it.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Less like a GTA clone this time, more like Infamous or Prototype. That's right, this time around you get superpowers.  It's a bit jarring if you've been following the series up to this point, but I cannot deny that it is FUN.

It's a little sad that cars are mostly useless in this game, especially given how easy it is to store, customize, and summon any vehicle this time around, but at the same time the various obscene superpowers you get are absolutely awesome.  There are sections where you can't use your superpowers, and honestly I think the game could use more. There are even text adventure and 2d side-scrolling beat-em-up sections!  This is not a bad thing, an adds some pleasant variety to the gaming experience.

The plot of the game is... interesting, much like any Saints Row game.  The villain is improbable and hateable, and the setup is... ridiculous. The plot also has a LOT of callbacks, references, and even new takes on elements from previous Saints Row games, all handled pretty well.  So that's nice.

There is one crappy element to the plot which I won't spoil, but it sort of puts a little damper on the whole thing, at least for me.  Not enough to make it un-fun, but... well if the Volition guys don't follow up on the plot somehow, I'mma be ♥♥♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
Saints Row IV or 4 does not fail to impress me! I can do absolutely anything I want in the game-... From jumping across the islands or by running into cars and turning them into flames - causing them to explode. The music in-game is fantastic! The atmosphere as soon as you start is fabulous and the overall combat system is exactly how I remember the Saints Row series being like!

- The guns are unique, alongside the general customerization that is possible! Loads of colours, shapes of guns, even different models of sizes and types for a specific gun slot! It's overall fantastic!
- The vehicles are generic, however the customerization again is excellant, being able to add body mods / colours / nos / a page of 50+ rims / it's grand!
- The plastic surgery part of the game which allows you to change; gender, race, facial features, bodily features, hair, skin, you name it! ^ I love being able to swap and change, going from a pink haired gym obsessive 6ft black guy, to a 5 ft round black guy with anime green hair and a beard! You name it, the possibilities are vast!
- The choice of doing main missions or side missions is grand! Without the main missions you can spend hours running around doing as you please! - So far I have 15 or so hours in Saints Row IV yet I have done around 10 main missions and the rest have been just from side quests and shooting bad guys!

I love the 80s music on certain radio stations and I also love the ability to add your own custom music <- however you'll need to follow a guide online and it takes ages!

Other than that, the only downfall... Saints Row IV offers a great experience to existing or new fans...

Being able to choose colourful clothes, or guns or cars... To people running around with giant monkey or cat masks... To men in gimp costumes... To energy drink cans shooting you with machine guns -... Toilets with guns... Spongey limbs and even having the same NPC spawned 20 times over with some deformity... It all adds into an amazing, unexpected, funny game, full of colour and diverse choice. I totally recommend it!
PS: I have taken a number of screenshots on Saints Row IV - 80 + to be precise, so go through them and definitely get the game :D!!!!

reviewText:
The Matrix meets Mass Effect Parody

Genre: Open World Action

Yea!
-Funny and over the top
-Superpowers
-Great soundtrack
-Same ol' SR gameplay filled with fun activities and decent combat and driving

Meh!
-Flying and sprinting super powers makes cars useless
-Lots of items to collect and I mean a lot
-Pretty much every place is copied from SR3

Bleh!
-More like an expansion to Saints Row 3
-Starts off well and starts to fizzle quickly on the story
-Kind of on the short side

The Lowdown

In the open world 3rd person action genre you have a few contenders. On the serious note you have Sleeping dogs and Watch Dogs. In the middle you have GTA where the overall tone is serious but throws quite a few comedic relief characters at you. Then you have Saints Row where it just throws ridiculous situations and mechanics at you that its just crazy. With that being said you can not even call this a GTA clone anymore as the only thing tat it has in common with the former is the 3rd person action genre. Saints Row is full of activities, comedy, one liners, aliens and TONS of collectables. Throw in some super powers and you think this game would be epic., they are fun and all but some of them make other gameplay mechanics we are use to obselete. Driving now becomes useless since you can fly and super run faster then driving, this basically just turns cars into objects to ram into while running to knock out of the way or to use as weapons to throw at enemies. With this i felt like i missed a great portion of the awesome soundtrack, from what i rarely got to hear it was great selection.
While the story of aliens invading earth and putting you into a Matrix" like simulator is insane
date: it does offer a lot of comedic moments. From the first mission of straddling a nuclear warhead to fighting alongside Rodney Piper
recommended: it has alot of LOL moments and pop culture references. Unfortunately towards the climax I felt the story lost its steam and just wanted it to end as it was just too cliche at that point. While I did not do all the side mission i did end up with completing 39/45 available missions and completed the game in a shy over 11 hours making this very short for a AAA release. And speaking of it being a AAA release

reviewText:
9/10
A wonderful open-world toybox of a game full of humour. It's more of the same silliness from SR3 (which I loved) but taken up a further notch with a Matrix style artificial reality, new superhero powers and an alien invasion to fight.

I've seen some complaints that it keeps the same engine as SR3 but it really still looks pretty good and the new powers provide a genuine change in play style. The devs play around a lot with deliberate graphical glitches and sillyness which also helps any minor graphics issues get overlooked.

On a personal note I'd probably have got this earlier and paid more for it if the devs weren't so relentless in the huge amount of paid for DLC that they ALWAYS churn out in the months after release. Still, they're all out now and come boxed with Game of the Century Edition. Get it for £5 on sale and it's a real bargain.

reviewText:
Gameplay: The addition of super powers to Saints Row IV makes the gameplay much more fun throughout the approximately 10 hour campaign. Super jump, super sprint and a host of other abilities turn ordinary enemy encounters and travelling into much more enjoyable experiences than they otherwise normally would be. As well as this the general gunplay is quite satisfying, but unfortunately the driving is the weakest aspect (although this becomes irrelevant very early into the game, as your super powers make using traditional vehicles uneccessary, save for certain scripted sections).

Story: The game is consistently well written, with witty dialogue from most minor and major characters, an interesting narrative and many humorous moments.

Graphics: The city is very much a replica of Steelport from Saints Row: The Third, but some unique visual effects make it seem unique. This visual design also extends to the characters and weapons, which are pseudo-realistic in design, with lots of detail and character.

Sound: The game's soundtrack is very good, with lots of exciting songs that make the gameplay more thrilling and enjoyable. The voice acting is also very good, with characters portraying many subtleties through their intonations and general dialogues.

Re-playability: There are literally over a thousand various collectables scattered throughout the world, an abundance of activities to complete, many character progressions to earn and buy, and much more. In total there is about 35 hours of gameplay, for the completionist.

reviewText: Saints Row IV is a video game that tries to be everything... and actually does a great job at it. The story continues from SR3, where the Leader of the Third Street Saints has gained enough popularity to become President. While the aspect of being US President is quicky diminished by an alien attack, it doesn't hurt the ridicolously over-the-top, hilarious and fun narrative. The most drastic change for franchise long-timers is that your avatar now has superpowers. This is easily the best thing about the game, despite that it destorys the point of driving cars in a franchise that was previously known as a GTA clone. The open-world is arguably less interesting than what it was in SR3, but the side content is addicting, fun, sometimes crazy, and worth it. Add in a co-op campaign option, and mind=blown. This game is fun in it's rawest state. 9/10\n\n(The Game has a free weekend, I totally recommend trying it out! Message me if you wanna play some co-op)

reviewText:
this game is stupiditly fun. for all the clasification issues, removed items, internet hate, and bad reviews, there is a whole lot more love as well. a LOT MORE.
first of all, the copycat problem. this game is NOT a copy of GTA in any way. can you explode aliens heads with rays in a simulated world in GTA? NO! thats because this game takes the average game, and SMOOSHES it down the drain.
the game has infinite posabilities as well. do you feel like blowing up a group of dancing hot dogs using super fireballs? well, you can! you can do practicaly anything you want. it's that big.
now here we are. no, in no way is this game worse because of the recycled city. think about this for a second. after sr2, imagine if volition recycled the city of stilwater AGAIN. sr3 would have been a dreadful hit. everyone would be hating on it because of the reused town. so, volition made a new city. and people hated them. but, imagine if volition had used the city for all the SR games. this game would have gotten nowhere sales-wise. i am glad that the steelport town was used again for this game. no joke.
finally, are the superpowers worth the extra money? yes. they bring a whole new element of gameplay to an already existing genre. the endless hours of fun seen in other SR games are made better with these powers, because it allows more freedom, more quickly, and more gameplay, more smoothly.
the story had been improved as well. instead of the silly sex jokes constintly used in the third game, this game uses well-written humor to its advantage. i grew attached to zinyak, the evil alien, due to his constant enjoyable cutscenes and speeches.

this game improves over saints row the third in almost every aspect. the gameplay is smoother, the characters are more customisable (with a new feature that allows for change of pitch), the story is more involved, the humor is smart, and the game has so much to offer.
so is it the best in the series? in my opinion, yes. before you storm me and destroy me, remember the order i have played the sr series in: SR3, SR4, SR2 (still finishing), and soon, SR. i am currently prefering it over SR2 because i find the missions and cutscenes a lot more exciting and open-eyed, with inclusion of licensed music and motion capture.

this game is not only my favourite of the year, but has to be one of the best i have ever played, along the lines of the legend of zelda - majoras mask, and the elder scrolls V - skyrim.

i give this title: 10/10

reviewText: Silly as frick. The story isn't as consistently, jaw-droppingly inspired in its absurd escalations as SR3, but the game plays way better. As a counterpoint to GTA 5, which was the deathknell of the open-world crime game by way of being mired in its conventions and weirdly vicious approach to everything, SR4 is the deathknell by way of showing the absolute limits of what you can do with the formula. What I mean is, within the first hour you get superpowers that let you jump really high, run really fast, and basically fly. Combined, all three of these make stealing in a car, driving around and committing crimes seem antiquated and ridiculous. It's faster and more satisfying to super-run through cars, super jump across rooftops, and fly.\n\nIt is hard to talk about what happens in the game without giving away huge spoilers, but let's just say that its entire tone is a very knowing sense of the word badical." It takes itself very seriously
date: even when the things it is taking seriously are how totally badass it was that you just climbed a really tall tower and got to the top
recommended: or how a confrontation with the alien overlord starts with you
hoursPlayed: the President of the United States
voteText: jumping out of the huge 8-barrel POTUS-branded AA cannon that is stationed on the White House lawn
helpfulPercent: and running at the crashed alien scout you just shot down
votesHelpful: jumping at the front window and shooting it out with a pistol and immediately engaging in a Rowdy Roddy Piper/Keith David "They Live"-esque brawl with said overlord.\n\nAnyone who takes it seriously and makes a character that looks remotely realistic is absolutely playing the game completely wrong and seems to have missed the pitch slider on the voices. The game is basically Your Fricking Ridiculous Power Fantasy: The Game
votesTotal: and is designed around both exceeding your wildest expectations while also subverting them. If there is one thing that the game is willing to critique
votesFunny: it is itself; its existence
commentsCount: your desire to play it
column16: and the video game industry as a whole. It's never condescending when it does this
column17: and comes across as the wet fever dream of a designer at the end of their life
column18: transcribed via dying breaths
column19: and developed as a celebratory eulogy to everything that once was. Its comments are made with a light touch
column20: even when the game itself is so intent on destroying the world and starting over.\n\nGreat game."

reviewText:
Wow. Just wow. The story is amazing. The characters are fantastic and hilarious. This was such an amazing game. There were lots of parody moments but even if you have no idea what's being referenced I don't think it would be less than a fantastic experience.

I loved the superpowers and it felt really fun to use them to traverse the city - even though you aren't really doing any 'exploring', just traveling was never boring. I never really enjoyed the driving in SR3 and still don't ~really~ enjoy it here, but it's become a moot point, and it's so much fun to just run and glide and jump through the city. Having the guns on top of the powers really mean that there's no way to get bored with combat, either, which was nice.

Everything ws put into this game, and while I definitely didn't enjoy the minigames/activites all the time, there were so many different types that I never was bored for more than a minute, until it ws no longer necessary to finish an activity and then you never really had to do more of that one again. They did a good job switching things up and keeping things mostly fresh.

Great game. Just absolutely fantastic.

reviewText:
As a long-time City of Heroes player, when I say that this game got the feeling of being a superhero down perfectly, I mean it. Especially once you've maxed out both super speed and super jump, you become a mixture of Neo and the Flash, with a little Goku thrown in, flinging yourself through the air, running up the sides of buildings, throwing around blasts of energy, and just generally kicking ♥♥♥ in the Matrix.

It took me ~25 hours to finish the game, getting _nearly_ ALL THE THINGS (even with the upgrade that shows collectables around you, I couldn't be ♥♥♥♥♥ to find absolutely all of them) - but I did complete all of the missions and side missions, and had a blast doing so.

I don't think that I'm rocking any boats here, but I would 100% recommend the game (especially on sale) for anyone.

reviewText:
Play as the leader of the Saints and president of the United States, abducted by aliens, trapped inside a matrix-like simulation that combines the typical american architecture with fancy, neon-glowing alien stuff and cause chaos with your super powers and a wide range of weapons starting with standard pistols/ shotguns/ rifles to giant hentai tentacles, the dubstep gun or the singularity gun while listening to an awesome soundtrack with songs like:

Montell Jordan - This Is How We Do It
Blur - Song 2
Zeds Dead - Demons
Vitalic - Stamina
Nero - Promises
Haddaway - What Is Love

And many many more. Techno, classic, dubstep, rock, EDM, rap, raggae. You won't be disappointed.

On top of that the game doesn't take itself very serious resulting in a great sense of humor, funny dialogues, cutscenes and tons of references to other games and movies.

10/10 Biggest fun I had in a while and praying for Saints Row V

reviewText:
Saint’s Row 4 is a GTA-themed sci-fi superhero sandbox game.

Yes, really.

Chock full of pop-culture references, jokes, crude humor, parodies of other intellectual properties, and general silliness, this game is a farce wrapped up in a superhero sandbox/sci-fi/GTA theme. The game does not take itself seriously at all, and yet, has remarkably high production values; the characters are fully voice acted, Keith David is your vice president, and you can eventually recruit Santa and Mrs. Claus as sidekicks.

The main attraction of this game is its over the top ridiculousness. The game starts out with your character breaking into a nuclear weapons facility to stop an insane general from launching a nuclear weapon and destroying Washington DC, and it only goes downhill from there. The protagonist is a sociopathic street-thug-♥♥♥-actor-♥♥♥-politician, who puts his ex-street thug friends in charge of the country.

And that’s just the first chapter. After that, aliens invade, everyone gets abducted and stuck into simulations of their worst nightmares – the protagonist gets stuck in a cheerful 50s-themed world – and eventually the protagonist breaks out, breaks into a GTA-themed simulation, and then frees all his friends from similarly ridiculous nightmare scenarios based on everything from fighting a gigantic can of soda to a 2D-beat-em-up to an old-school wireframe video game world. The protagonist gains superpowers over the course of the game, allowing him to completely turn the GTA-themed sandbox on its head, largely ignoring vehicles in favor of running around with super-speed and super-jumps and super-gliding, running up the sides of buildings and bouncing around the city.

The actual gameplay itself is often fairly mediocre; it mostly plays like an over-the-shoulder 3rd person shooter. And yet, the sheer ridiculousness of the scenarios, the constant comedic banter between the protagonist, his teammates, and the enemy, and the general lack of the game taking itself seriously somehow combine to make the game a generally enjoyable experience. The game is at its worst when you are slogging your way through waves of rather uninteresting enemies, but fortunately the protagonist is generally so overpowered after a while that apart from a few missions where you have limited weapons, you can pretty much crush them easily. The actual sandbox aspect of the game is fairly weak; there are a bunch of missions which more or less serve as practice for various bits of the game, as well as challenges which push your ability to complete tasks with various superpowers or weapons or vehicles to the limit, but on the whole most of these are fairly inoffensive, and they aren’t repetitive enough to be annoying.

So, is it good?

I’d say on the whole that it was an enjoyable experience; while the gameplay may not have been the best, the sheer chutzpah of the game actually made it pretty fun, and you never knew what ridiculous task you’d be up to next. The game does its best to make you feel powerful, and the game is, in the end, a power fantasy, an ego trip, and a comedy all wrapped up into one. It doesn’t take itself seriously, and neither should you, but on the whole, it was well worth it.

reviewText:
Once again, the Saints are back with some wacky adventures. Trapped inside a computer simulation, the game gives you free rein to kick some ♥♥♥ and get revenge for humanity.

Overall, Saints Row 4 is a VERY fun game. Saints Row is clearly now breaking away from another sandbox GTA style game to games where you can do random ♥♥♥♥ and have a lot of fun. This works for them very well and surprisingly, they deliver an exciting superhero game with a compelling, if at times ridiculous, story.

Fans of the Saints Row series will really enjoy the callbacks 4 makes to previous games (especially 2 and 3) but new players may be a little confused. I'd definitely recommend skimming the plots of previous games before playing 4.

I would probably still recommend 3 over 4 but this is still a great game with lots of fun to be had.

reviewText:
9/10
A wonderful open-world toybox of a game full of humour. It's more of the same silliness from SR3 (which I loved) but taken up a further notch with a Matrix style artificial reality, new superhero powers and an alien invasion to fight.

I've seen some complaints that it keeps the same engine as SR3 but it really still looks pretty good and the new powers provide a genuine change in play style. The devs play around a lot with deliberate graphical glitches and sillyness which also helps any minor graphics issues get overlooked.

On a personal note I'd probably have got this earlier and paid more for it if the devs weren't so relentless in the huge amount of paid for DLC that they ALWAYS churn out in the months after release. Still, they're all out now and come boxed with Game of the Century Edition. Get it for £5 on sale and it's a real bargain.

reviewText:
If you are a fan of the over the top fun that is Saints Row 3, you will enjoy 4, hands down. However, if you are of the school thinking this is some sort of serious open world crime game -cough gta cough- You will be dissapointed and wondering what the hell you just signed on for.   I myself, love the zany so I absolutely love what I have played so far.
the Pros:  it's fun, explodey, crude and general mayhem at it's best. There are alot of activities to do and plenty of them to keep you distracted for hours.

the cons: This port from console is a bit easy if you ask me. Certain mechanics, when transferred to mouse become second nature, vs fighting with a controller as the challenge. (the sprint challenges for example, with a controller would pose a bit more challenge than someone who has much more control via a mouse) my partner and I got gold on the hard ones on the first run through on most of them, if not the first, then the second.

There are a few...bugs? that I noticed that make the game a bit um...broken in the player's favor, but it's questionable if it was on purpose or not. As we are basically in a broken version of the matrix.  I discovered, to my absolute mirth, that during a fraud mission, I could send my character careening and cartwheeling clear across town, racking up hundreds of thousands of dollars in one fall. My mate topped my 350k by hitting 510k ..the bum!  But when the challenge hits gold at 1.6m, and you can easily accomplish this, it makes you wonder where the challenge is.

Now...mind you , storyline wise we have not progressed very far, as the darn cookie crumb activities keep distracting us! oh look a mayhem!!   So I am hoping it will get a bit tougher.

Overall, this game is a fantastic I've had a crappy day and need to unwind with random chaos and take my frustrations out in explosive form on pixels." type of game. It's what I've always considered the franchise. Fun

reviewText: The game itself is great, but what I found frustrating were the powers. At face value they seem cool, but over time I started feeling like the game experience was shallow because of them. Giant, unlimited explosions that killed everything around me made every gun in the game useless. Super-dashing took away any need to steal a car and make it my own with a custom paint job and meticulous body upgrades. Super-jumping took away the amazing feeling of stealing a plane or helicopter and parachuting out of an emergency landing. For every instant-gratification super power that emerged, it took away from a previous good feeling I had playing Saints Row 3.\n\nIt's a good game so I have to recommend it, but I feel a little sad because instead of getting more" of what I used to love

reviewText:
The biggest shame about Saints Row IV is that most people will ignore it as a bad GTA clone. In reality, though, this game is perhaps the most amazing super-villain simulator ever.

From the amazingly over-the-top story to the incredible selection of songs, which reminds me of what I loved about the last GTA I really loved, Vice City, it gets so much right that even where it goes wrong I'm willing to forgive it.

The only sandbox I've had as much fun in recently was Just Cause 2 which says a lot.

Get it.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Less like a GTA clone this time, more like Infamous or Prototype. That's right, this time around you get superpowers.  It's a bit jarring if you've been following the series up to this point, but I cannot deny that it is FUN.

It's a little sad that cars are mostly useless in this game, especially given how easy it is to store, customize, and summon any vehicle this time around, but at the same time the various obscene superpowers you get are absolutely awesome.  There are sections where you can't use your superpowers, and honestly I think the game could use more. There are even text adventure and 2d side-scrolling beat-em-up sections!  This is not a bad thing, an adds some pleasant variety to the gaming experience.

The plot of the game is... interesting, much like any Saints Row game.  The villain is improbable and hateable, and the setup is... ridiculous. The plot also has a LOT of callbacks, references, and even new takes on elements from previous Saints Row games, all handled pretty well.  So that's nice.

There is one crappy element to the plot which I won't spoil, but it sort of puts a little damper on the whole thing, at least for me.  Not enough to make it un-fun, but... well if the Volition guys don't follow up on the plot somehow, I'mma be ♥♥♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
Saint's Row IV is/was hilarious fun. I haven't played the previous installments of the franchise, and started straight into SR/IV which convinced me mainly because of the attributes that caused a many other fans headache: the added superpowers.

As a former veteran of the good old (and unfortunately also gone) MMORPGame City of Heroes/Villains (Superhero creation), I was looking for something that would fill the fun void that was caused when NCSoft shut down the game's servers and the Super Heroes and Villains soared into the evening sky for their last time.

But back to this game here:

The main thing you gotta know about Saints Row is that: it can't be taken seriously, yet you can't just classify it into just one game genre either: It's part 3rd-view-shooter, it's part adventure game, it's part exploration, and a whole fistful of fun if you're into character customization and generelly hilarious fun whatever the hell you decide to get up to.

You are able to collect a whole arsenal of all sorts of exotic weapons, out of which the Dubstep Gun" will be the most memorable one

reviewText:
As a long-time City of Heroes player, when I say that this game got the feeling of being a superhero down perfectly, I mean it. Especially once you've maxed out both super speed and super jump, you become a mixture of Neo and the Flash, with a little Goku thrown in, flinging yourself through the air, running up the sides of buildings, throwing around blasts of energy, and just generally kicking ♥♥♥ in the Matrix.

It took me ~25 hours to finish the game, getting _nearly_ ALL THE THINGS (even with the upgrade that shows collectables around you, I couldn't be ♥♥♥♥♥ to find absolutely all of them) - but I did complete all of the missions and side missions, and had a blast doing so.

I don't think that I'm rocking any boats here, but I would 100% recommend the game (especially on sale) for anyone.

reviewText:
First off, the game is not terrible.

That being said, having been a huge fan of Saints Row: The Third, my expectations where sky high going into Saints Row IV.

The story of the game is even more over the top than previous Saints Row titles, though, the same can be said for a lot of the other aspects of the game. To sum it up, the story was entertaining enough, however, I don't think anyone ever played a Saints Row game for the story, so I concider this more a positive bi-factor.

The gameplay, now the gameplay in SR4 adds a lot variety, the introduction of super powers allows for even more rampage and destruction than ever before. With Blast powers, Telekinesis, Super jump and sprint, your character becomes a big ball of destruction goodness.

However, while super powers is a lot of fun to play around with, I feel it also takes a lot away from the game. The game is INCREDIBLY easy, even on the hardest difficulty. Activities from previous SR games, like Insurance Fraud" devolves into super jumping

reviewText: Saints Row IV is a video game that tries to be everything... and actually does a great job at it. The story continues from SR3, where the Leader of the Third Street Saints has gained enough popularity to become President. While the aspect of being US President is quicky diminished by an alien attack, it doesn't hurt the ridicolously over-the-top, hilarious and fun narrative. The most drastic change for franchise long-timers is that your avatar now has superpowers. This is easily the best thing about the game, despite that it destorys the point of driving cars in a franchise that was previously known as a GTA clone. The open-world is arguably less interesting than what it was in SR3, but the side content is addicting, fun, sometimes crazy, and worth it. Add in a co-op campaign option, and mind=blown. This game is fun in it's rawest state. 9/10\n\n(The Game has a free weekend, I totally recommend trying it out! Message me if you wanna play some co-op)

reviewText:
Shrek's Row 4 is a fantastic game all around. They took Shrek's Row the Third and shifted into maximum ogredrive. It is stylized with multiple layers much like an onion or an ogre and has a plethra of orge-wordly powers for you to crush your enemies with. The soundtrack is other songs that were already made but placed into the game because Shrek said so, much like the first movie. The story follows Shrek as he embarks on a journey to take back his swamp and crush Farquaad and his cult of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ socks who fail to realize Shrek as their one true ogrelord while also ♥♥♥♥ing everybody he doesn't murder first (and on one occasion he does both) with a weapon that fires dubstep so wannabe the hipsters have even more reason to complain about the game for being Shrek-tacular. If you liked Shrek's Row 2 or The Third, you will like this as it combines both of the previous spiritual journey's types and structures of humogre into a perfect, Shrek-tacular blend of clever parody and sex jokes.

Shrek is Love, Shrek is life.

10/10 donate your money to Shrek right now.

reviewText:
Saint’s Row 4 is a GTA-themed sci-fi superhero sandbox game.

Yes, really.

Chock full of pop-culture references, jokes, crude humor, parodies of other intellectual properties, and general silliness, this game is a farce wrapped up in a superhero sandbox/sci-fi/GTA theme. The game does not take itself seriously at all, and yet, has remarkably high production values; the characters are fully voice acted, Keith David is your vice president, and you can eventually recruit Santa and Mrs. Claus as sidekicks.

The main attraction of this game is its over the top ridiculousness. The game starts out with your character breaking into a nuclear weapons facility to stop an insane general from launching a nuclear weapon and destroying Washington DC, and it only goes downhill from there. The protagonist is a sociopathic street-thug-♥♥♥-actor-♥♥♥-politician, who puts his ex-street thug friends in charge of the country.

And that’s just the first chapter. After that, aliens invade, everyone gets abducted and stuck into simulations of their worst nightmares – the protagonist gets stuck in a cheerful 50s-themed world – and eventually the protagonist breaks out, breaks into a GTA-themed simulation, and then frees all his friends from similarly ridiculous nightmare scenarios based on everything from fighting a gigantic can of soda to a 2D-beat-em-up to an old-school wireframe video game world. The protagonist gains superpowers over the course of the game, allowing him to completely turn the GTA-themed sandbox on its head, largely ignoring vehicles in favor of running around with super-speed and super-jumps and super-gliding, running up the sides of buildings and bouncing around the city.

The actual gameplay itself is often fairly mediocre; it mostly plays like an over-the-shoulder 3rd person shooter. And yet, the sheer ridiculousness of the scenarios, the constant comedic banter between the protagonist, his teammates, and the enemy, and the general lack of the game taking itself seriously somehow combine to make the game a generally enjoyable experience. The game is at its worst when you are slogging your way through waves of rather uninteresting enemies, but fortunately the protagonist is generally so overpowered after a while that apart from a few missions where you have limited weapons, you can pretty much crush them easily. The actual sandbox aspect of the game is fairly weak; there are a bunch of missions which more or less serve as practice for various bits of the game, as well as challenges which push your ability to complete tasks with various superpowers or weapons or vehicles to the limit, but on the whole most of these are fairly inoffensive, and they aren’t repetitive enough to be annoying.

So, is it good?

I’d say on the whole that it was an enjoyable experience; while the gameplay may not have been the best, the sheer chutzpah of the game actually made it pretty fun, and you never knew what ridiculous task you’d be up to next. The game does its best to make you feel powerful, and the game is, in the end, a power fantasy, an ego trip, and a comedy all wrapped up into one. It doesn’t take itself seriously, and neither should you, but on the whole, it was well worth it.

Rating (5/10 = failure): 9.5
Multiplayer: Yes (2)
Completion: 23 hrs
Cards: Yes
Cloud: Yes
Cost: 20 USD

reviewText:
This game, is absolutely chaotically amazing, It knows it's a parody and starts off knowing that, with a small mission that involves riding a rocket and disarming it while in mid flight only to land safely into the white house oval office chair to the very end.

The Good : - Absolutely funny
- Co-Op gameplay makes this even more amazing
- Super Powers are absolutely fun
- Character Customisation
- A lot of Customisation
- Chaotic often
- Good voice acting
- An Actual good story
- Fun gameplay despite being absolutely a bunch of destroyers with the best powers and best weapons
- A lot of Activities

The Bad : - Same location and same mechanics as Saints Row 3
- Same graphics as Saints Row 3
- A lot of same things with Saints Row 3
- No heavy Metal station ( :< )
- Basically an Expansion from the Third
If you haven't played the Third, I'd say skip it and go straight to this as this is the stronger Saints Row out of the 2, but 2 is definitely the strongest but absolutely broken for PC so enjoy this game instead, You are guaranteed a fun time if you come into this ready to be silly and destructive.

reviewText:
Overall this was pretty fun to co-op through. Although, I'm not a fan of the direction they took saints row. The superpowers are fun at first, but overall they diminish the whole experience. There's nothing wrong with having to drive around the city to get where you are going. With the superpowers, I don't think I set foot in a car once. And the superpowers shortened the game considerably.

With this said, this was still a good game. You can tell they put a lot of work into it, and at times I was laughing my ♥♥♥ off - just not as often as I was in saints row 3.

I can always depend on saints row to provide a fun co-op experience, but I really hope they take the game back to basics and focus on funny rather than ridiculous. I know they are trying to separate themselves from gta, but they can do it via parody and comedy rather than crazy gameplay physics.

Ideally, the next installment will have the basic nature of saints row 2 with the comedy and parody of saints row 3.

reviewText: Se non contiamo il  Saints Row: Gat out of Hell, spin-off della serie allora SAINTS ROW4 è  l'ultimo capitolo principale.Doveva essere un DLC\espansione di Saints Row3 ma la sua grandezza ha permesso alla Volition di creare un nuovo capitolo.In questo nuovo capitolo i nostri eroi hanno fatto passi da gigante ancora una volta,questa volta però hanno puntato alla casa bianca,il nostro  personaggio infatti sarà il presidente degli stati uniti.....Un presidente abbastanza bravo da come si dice nel gioco,avendo risanato il debito pubblico.Comunque questa carica presidenziale viene messa in gioco da un invasione aliena la quale cattura tutta la nostra gang  alla quale si sono uniti Asha una spia del M16 e Benjamin King  incontrato nel primo Saints Row è  il leader dei Vice Kings eliminati in Saints Row2.\nOvviamente l'umanità  viene sconfitta è  quasi tutta la nostra gang viene  portata sulla nave madre e messi tutti in criostasi.Questa criostasi consiste nel far immergere le persone in un mondo virtuale basato sugli incubi delle varie persone,il nostro personaggio sarà intrappolato negli anni 50 in un mondo dove non si possono dire le parolacce.Da qui in avanti si comincerà a combattere gli alieni ed i loro mondi virtuali,infatti con l'aiuto di Kinzie saremmo inseriti in una stellport virtuale.\nGraficamente parlando il gioco cambia di poco anche se si nota ovviamente una  pulizia generare della qualità,il frame rate è più stabile anche se ho notato che durante le cut-scene" queste non vanno mai oltre i 30 frame.La personalizzazione del personaggio rimane alta come quella vista in Saints Row 3

reviewText: So Saints Row 4 is WAY different than Saints Row 1 and 2, so if you want something similar, stay far away from this game.  This is a lot more fast paced and a lot less challenging.  It still has the humor of Saints Row but with a little more sex jokes and a lot more cussing, so if you aren't into that kind of humor than you might not enjoy this game.  The gameplay is very different from other SR games.  In this game taking cover is completely useless and your best strategy is to run circles around your enemies with your super sprint and use your sprint takedowns.  Yeah remember those sprint takedowns that were useless in Saints Row The Third?  Yeah, they are overpowered as hell now.  Guns are horrible in most cases so upgrading your guns is a huge waste of money.  This game is really easy as long as you aren't acting really stupid during combat.  The superpowers are definitely the best part about the game.  My favorite thing to do is to climb the towers using the superpowers.  Overall, it is a fun game but is not similar to the older games in any way and is not very challenging.  If you are looking for fun I would recommend this game.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Great game, fantastic gameplay of mayhem and explosions, and a really whacky storyline.

Game explores and develops the concept of various superpowers in Saints Row The Third, making blowing stuff up 500% more awesome, with super sprints, fireballs, and giant mech suits.
Steelport is identical to how it was in The Third, and the dark sky throughout the initial playthrough may be visually dull after spending the first 10-20 hours in game.

Vehicles are useless because of super sprints and leap given in the first half hour in the simulation, which allows you to run faster than cars.

Lots of references and parodies to other games and movies and generic alien stererotypes.
Funny dialogues between characters, and the scriptwriting is brilliant.

Unique weapons such as the Dubstep Gun, Rectifier (haha) and Singularity (Black hole gun) is just simply awesome!

Definitely not a Gang Simulator like it was before, and more of a game purely made for blowing stuff up, and enjoying complete freedom in a open-world setting.

If you played any of the previous Saints Row, get this game. :D

reviewText: Saints Row 4 was the first game out of the Saints Row Franchise that I ever played. The way I see it, it appears as a super-powered sandbox game with a higher grade of technology. The game follows a somewhat strong storyline and has some interesting side missions, unlike Saints Row: The Third, where there were no more missions after the story was complete.\n\nFocusing more on the weapons, it seems that Deep Silver Volition went a little bit overboard with the humor of some of the weapons, mainly centering the Dubstep Gun, the Inflato-Ray, and the Plunger Gun. I disliked the Inflato-Ray and the Plunger Gun, but the Dubstep Gun was interesting. To be honest, I kind of wished that DSV (Deep Silver Volition) named the remaining weapons (SMGs, Rifles, Shotguns, etc.) like Saints Row: The Third. I felt I was playing at a more realistic level in those games, and when it came to Saints Row 4, you get names like the Quickshot Pistol" or the "Pump-Action Shotgun". Not saying that's bad
date: just a little vague.\n\nOne of my favorite features of the game was using former villains as my sidekicks in intense battles like taking out flashpoints or taking down wardens. I loved making rival combinations like Benjamin King and Tanya

reviewText:
Although I am disappointed that AU only has access to the low violence version of this game, I shall digress. Starting off as a kick-♥♥♥ president whom runs the White House on their own terms, to completely obliterating alien scum with your weaponry or with one of your various superpowers for that matter.  It’s easy to say Saints Row IV is incredibly engaging and entertaining. There's never a dull moment!

You might be left questioning Santa’s motives, other than that though it’s reasonably above board… I’m kidding of course when is anything to do with the saints above board? To spite what others have said, I’ve found it incredibly easy to navigate with mouse and keyboard for this game. If your lack of owning a controller is the only thing that is stopping you from experiencing this game, don’t let it!
10/10 Fun for the whole gang.

reviewText:
WOW, this game is a dissapointment. Coming off of a smashing success in Saints Row 2 and 3, fans of the franchise were used to gangs, shootouts, and other stuff that is more fun than generic aliens. Simply said, this game goes down fast and hard. It is NOT worth 17 dollars, I got it for free using AMD games with gold for my gpu. The plot is generic, and I can not force myself to try to progress in this game any farther. Onto the Pros and Cons.

Pros:
Funny, (sometimes)
Great references
Good customization,
Good weapons (BUT NOT FOR THE ENTIRE FIRST QUATER OF THE GAME!)
effort put into designs on cars and other ♥♥♥♥.

Cons:
Crap story, (ok I get it, its SAINTS ROW, not the sopranos, but at least dont make it generic like they did,)
NPC'S are just there to be in the way
Graphics pretty much suck.
weapons are dismal for the most part, ecept america gun, dubstep gun, etc.
Enemies are TERRIBLE
Minimap and driving are no good.
Even though driving sucks, all the cars become useless after OP superpowers, wich is the only reason to come back to the game after beating it.
And the worst part is the backdrop of the simulation world. It is a dark red/black/grey/♥♥♥♥ collor that makes the game ugly and bad to look at. Can we just have a bright blue sky? That would make Simulation steelport shine really well. You can only change the time of day after beating the game.
Also, no challenge at all, its just a chore to beat the game so you can ♥♥♥♥ around.

FINAL VERDICT, 5/10, SUPERHERO SIMULATOR, HARDRIVE SPACE TAKER.

reviewText:
The most fun I've had in a game in a long time!!!  The game is just epic fun and has insane weapons; one of the melee weapons.. is a huge like alien butt probe and its like wtfff?! But my favorite of the melee weps. so far is the tentacle, it's fairly stong and hilarious when u thwack people and they go flying!

The game's music for everything is awesome, and the objectives around the map are quite fun. The game is like GTA but you can run crazy fast and jump high as a skyscraper. Once you start getting powers early-game you become insanely strong and your survivalability goes through the roof. You can just run away from stuff to reload / recharge your guns or just run away till people aren't trying to kill you. I'd def suggest getting the game if its on sale, I didn't buy any dlc but looks like theres a lot; but u have a tonn of customization options even without the dlc, which is a rare thing in this day an age lol.

10/10 EPIC FUN GAME

100/10 When you make the Dubstep gun explosive

Although I am disappointed that AU only has access to the low violence version of this game, I shall digress. Starting off as a kick-♥♥♥ president whom runs the White House on their own terms, to completely obliterating alien scum with your weaponry or with one of your various superpowers for that matter.  It’s easy to say Saints Row IV is incredibly engaging and entertaining. There's never a dull moment!

You might be left questioning Santa’s motives, other than that though it’s reasonably above board… I’m kidding of course when is anything to do with the saints above board? To spite what others have said, I’ve found it incredibly easy to navigate with mouse and keyboard for this game. If your lack of owning a controller is the only thing that is stopping you from experiencing this game, don’t let it!
10/10 Fun for the whole gang.

reviewText:
WOW, this game is a dissapointment. Coming off of a smashing success in Saints Row 2 and 3, fans of the franchise were used to gangs, shootouts, and other stuff that is more fun than generic aliens. Simply said, this game goes down fast and hard. It is NOT worth 17 dollars, I got it for free using AMD games with gold for my gpu. The plot is generic, and I can not force myself to try to progress in this game any farther. Onto the Pros and Cons.

Pros:
Funny, (sometimes)
Great references
Good customization,
Good weapons (BUT NOT FOR THE ENTIRE FIRST QUATER OF THE GAME!)
effort put into designs on cars and other ♥♥♥♥.

Cons:
Crap story, (ok I get it, its SAINTS ROW, not the sopranos, but at least dont make it generic like they did,)
NPC'S are just there to be in the way
Graphics pretty much suck.
weapons are dismal for the most part, ecept america gun, dubstep gun, etc.
Enemies are TERRIBLE
Minimap and driving are no good.
Even though driving sucks, all the cars become useless after OP superpowers, wich is the only reason to come back to the game after beating it.
And the worst part is the backdrop of the simulation world. It is a dark red/black/grey/♥♥♥♥ collor that makes the game ugly and bad to look at. Can we just have a bright blue sky? That would make Simulation steelport shine really well. You can only change the time of day after beating the game.
Also, no challenge at all, its just a chore to beat the game so you can ♥♥♥♥ around.

FINAL VERDICT, 5/10, SUPERHERO SIMULATOR, HARDRIVE SPACE TAKER.

reviewText:
This game is fun... if you are 13 and mentally r*tarded.

I don't even know where to start. First, the developers try you to go deaf by ridiculously loud intro logo screen. I'm serious, be careful. The physics are bad, driving is anything but enjoyable, I did some random missions on the map and they were horribly boring, the whole game is just SO SO UNFUNNY. It's so embarrassing. Maybe I just like some more sophisticated humor. This is literally like for 10 year old boys.

If you want some over-the-top nonsense, go for Just Cause 2. It's cheesy in a good way and a lot of fun.

reviewText:
This game gradually differentiated itself more from Grand Theft Auto with each game. This game features aliens and super powers, and is LOADS of fun.
Pros:
-VERY relaxing collecting and destroying the items and locations throughout the city.
-Built in radio channels with great music of every genre. Even create your own mixtape!
-Tons of minigames that do not get extremely tedious overtime.
-Ability to sprint at speeds rivaling Sonic the Hedgehog :-)
-Can be bought for very reasonable prices during a sale (including all DLC)
Cons:
-The explosive powerup DLC is extremely broken and overpowered, but it can be disabled.

Overall 9/10 - I would recommend picking up this game to nearly everyone.
